pages.subdeck: Mum ... Rose wants reunion with Mario Balotelli
pages.headline: Mam City
pages.teaser: WHILE £120k-a-week star lives in a mansion, birth mum moves to local council house
pages.articlebody:
MARIO Balotelli's mum has moved to one of Britain's toughest council estates as she rekindles her relationship with the son she gave away as a child.

While the £120,000-a-week footballer lives in a mansion and a plush hotel, Rose Barwuah rents a £550-a-month terraced house in part of Manchester made famous by TV's Shameless.

Manchester City striker Mario, 21, has visited her in Wythenshawe  driving his white Bentley GT, popping to shops and even standing his round in a pub.

A neighbour said: "Rose is a religious woman who goes to church every Sunday. All she has ever wanted was to rebuild their relationship and now it looks like her prayers have been answered."

Ghanaian immigrants Rose, 46, and hubby Thomas were advised to hand Mario to foster parents when he was two.

They were living in a cramped flat in Brescia, Italy, and he was recovering from operations on his intestines.

They said the richer Balotelli family who took him in then turned him against them.

The player dubbed Super Mario by fans went on to star for Inter Milan before being bought by City for £23million.

He reacted angrily when Rose and Thomas first said they want to be reunited with him, claiming they were just after his money.

But Rose, who barely speaks English, showed her determination for a reconciliation by moving with her 13-year-old daughter Angel.

Her other son, 18-year-old Enoch, is a promising footballer in England after trials with Stoke and Sunderland while daughter Abigail, 23, runs a fashion store near Milan.

Abigail told The Sun: "My mum will be closer to Mario and Enoch but I will stay here."

And Giuseppe Toninelli, owner of the metal works where Thomas has worked for 15 years, said: "He has left. He was going to Ghana before joining the family in Manchester.

"I think they are all trying to patch up their differences."

A neighbour in Wythenshawe said: "Rose is doing this herself to show it is not about money.

"This is the house she can afford. All she wants to do is to get to know her son.

"Rose has settled in here. She works at Wythenshawe Market, setting off before 6am to put out the stalls for traders.

"Mario has started coming round more often. He sometimes strolls to the shop for her.

"He has been friendly too and signed some kits. He has been to the local pub, The Tudor, and even put money behind the bar. It is lovely that he and Rose are close again."

Mario  who lives in posh Alderley Edge, Cheshire, and the city centre Hilton Hotel  played last night in City's 1-1 draw at Stoke.



His pad

AS well as his £3million mansion, Mario has been living in a £975-a-night suite at Manchester's five-star Hilton Hotel.

CLAIM TO FAME: Some of the most spectacular views over Manchester.

FACILITIES: Swimming pool, spa, ballroom.

FAMOUS FACES: TV stars plus players and WAGs from City and United.



Her pad

ROSE lives in a terraced house in Wythenshawe.

CLAIM TO FAME: Created in the 1920s as a "garden city".

FACILITIES: Airport cargo centre, shopping mall, multi-storey car park.

FAMOUS FACES: The Duchess of York  visiting in 2009 to make a TV documentary called The Duchess On The Estate.

pages.articlebody:
FURIOUS Tulisa Contostavlos is suing her ex for £100,000 over her leaked sex tape  scaring him into silence.

Lawyers for the X Factor judge slapped legal papers on wannabe rap star Justin Edwards, 28.

A source close to Edwards said: "He feels he can't talk publicly now because of this."

Tulisa, 23, wants damages for breach of confidence and privacy after the video of her performing a sex act went up for sale on the internet.

Former N-Dubz singer Tulisa got a High Court injunction to ban the £3.90 tape last week.

The devastated beauty says Edwards is the man in the six-minute video. But he denies her claim that he leaked it.

Edwards has been hiding out in the West Country since the storm erupted and has been bombarded with abuse on Twitter by Tulisa fans.

The legal papers were served at a house where his mother lives in West Hampstead, North London. He was not there at the time.

A source close to Edwards, who calls himself MC Ultra, said last night: "She's suing for up to £100,000. This latest move by Tulisa has really unnerved and unsettled him.

"It's serious stuff and he's got to take it seriously. It's a lot of pressure for him."

A legal source said: "This is an unusual case, in that the injunction was granted AFTER the material became public, not before. It entitles Tulisa to seek damages."

An application to extend Tulisa's emergency injunction will be heard at the High Court in London tomorrow.

pages.subdeck: Donations scandal ... Conservative Party co-treasurer Peter Cruddas
pages.headline: £250k gets you dinner with PM
pages.teaser: TORY fundraiser resigns after being filmed offering access to David Cameron for a donation
pages.byline: By DAVID WOODING, Associate Political Editor
pages.articlebody:
A TORY fundraiser quit early today after he was accused of brokering meetings with David Cameron in return for huge donations.

Co-treasurer Peter Cruddas was filmed offering a lobbyist and her two overseas clients direct access to the PM for £250,000.

The trader invited them to join the "premier league" of donors  adding there was no point "scratching around" with donations of £10,000.

David Cameron today called Cruddas's promises "completely unacceptable" and "shouldn't have happened".

Speaking at a Sports Relief run in Buckinghamshire, Mr Cameron added that there would be an inquiry to make sure such claims were never made again.

Labour MP David Miliband said this morning: "The idea that policy is for sale is grotesque."

Cruddas is said to have made the offer of access despite thinking the cash would come from Liechtenstein  which would be illegal.

Cruddas  worth an estimated £750million to £1billion  is heard boasting in a video: "Some of our bigger donors have been for dinner in Number 10 Downing Street in the Prime Minister's private apartment, with Samantha."

Cruddas  caught by a Sunday Times sting  also says: "Things will open up for you, but you need to go in with a bit of, you know  it's no good scratching around and it's ten grand or 75 grand."

He goes on: "A hundred grand is not premier league.

"It's not bad  it's probably bottom of the premier league. Two hundred grand or 250 is premier league.

"You will be able to ask him practically any question that you want."

He says later: "If you're unhappy about something, we'll listen to you and we'll put it into the policy committee at Number 10.

"It'll be awesome for your business."

After quitting early today Cruddas said: "I deeply regret any impression of impropriety arising from my bluster in that conversation.

"Clearly there is no question of donors being able to influence policy or gain undue access to politicians."

pages.subdeck: New laws ... Theresa May
pages.headline: Migrant marriage sham ban
pages.teaser: IMMIGRANTS to be stopped using sham marriages as a 'back door' into Britain
pages.byline: By DAVID WOODING, Associate Political Editor
pages.articlebody:
IMMIGRANTS are to be STOPPED using sham marriages as a "back door" into Britain in a tough new government crackdown.

UK citizens will be banned from bringing foreign spouses to live here unless they can afford to support them.

They will have to earn at least £25,700 a year under plans by Home Secretary Theresa May.

The minimum income would rise up to £62,600 if they want to bring kids in too.

Newlyweds face a five-year trial before staying.

Details of the immigration blitz are contained in a leaked Cabinet document seen by The Sun.

Mrs May believes the action will cut the number of non-EU migrants by 15,000 a year.

She will face bitter opposition from Lib Dem coalition partners, already fuming over last week's Budget.

But the leaked letter  from Mrs May to Deputy PM Nick Clegg  shows she is determined to make a stand.

She believes action to tighten the "family route" into UK won huge public support in last year's consultation.

Around 50,000 visas were given to family of UK citizens in 2011  a fifth of all non-EU migrants.

Most of those arriving here under that route are women from Pakistan, India and Bangladesh But many end up living with jobless or low-earners and become a burden on the benefit system.

Mrs May writes in her letter: "The package which I propose to implement from June 2012 will reduce the burdens on the taxpayer, promote integration and tackle abuse."

She insists there is a need to "differentiate between genuine and non-genuine relationships".

The minimum income more than doubles the current threshold and spouses will have to learn English to a higher standard.

For a partner with one child, the income threshold would rise to £37,000 a year. It would hit £62,600 for those with three.

pages.subdeck: 'Attack' ... mallard struck windscreen
pages.headline: Weirdest car smash claims
pages.teaser: KAMIKAZE ducks, snowballs and Subo CD among bizarre list of claim items
pages.articlebody:
KAMIKAZE ducks, snowballs and a Subo CD are among a bizarre list of items which have damaged Brit motorists' cars in the past year.

Another female driver complained she was being stalked by "an evil pheasant" which had attacked her vehicle.

While one man needed help after accidentally firing his shotgun inside his vehicle, Autoglass revealed in their annual round-up of wacky claims.

The SuBo call-out was sparked after a driver used her CD to scrape ice off his windscreen.

In another incident, a snowball shattered a side window, while one driver summoned help after damage caused after he parked in front of a tee at a golf course.

One woman called to arrange a repair to a chipped windscreen but then realised her son had stuck a sweet to the inside of the screen.

Another driver complained of a rattling windscreen when the problem was an air freshener hitting the glass

One man called to have a cracked rear window dealt with before realising that the problem was with someone else's car and that his was own motor parked close by.

Autoglass boss Matthew Mycock said: "Our technicians are always ready to deal with the unexpected but even they are sometimes surprised by the calls they receive.

"The UK's potholed and congested roads don't make things easy for motorists but sometimes it seems vehicle and glass damage is self-inflicted or the result of freak occurrences."

pages.subdeck: Front line ... Gareth and Rachel prove love can bloom on the battlefield
pages.headline: Newlywed soldier couple honeymoon in war-torn Helmand
pages.teaser: RACHEL and Gareth Mawsdley enjoy start of married life on the battlefield
pages.articlebody:
A NEWLYWED couple are enjoying a novel start to married life - with a honeymoon in war-torn Helmand.

Squadron Leader Rachel and Lieutenant Commander Gareth Mawsdley enjoyed a fairytale wedding at a Georgian manor house last year.

But they were only able to spend a few nights together before training began for their tours of Afghanistan.

The couple, who met through their roles in the military and live in Bath, both began a six-month spell at Camp Bastion, Britain's main military base in Afghanistan, in November.

While they admit a war zone would not be their first choice of honeymoon destination, they still find time for romance.

Rachel, 35, from Newbury near Reading, is in the RAF while Gareth, 32, from Liverpool, is in the Navy.

They recently marked their six month anniversary in a steak house on the desert base.

Gareth said: "There's no alcohol on base so we each had a can of pop instead of a bottle of wine.

"As we shared some nachos, we were surrounded by US marines and everybody was carrying weapons.

"But when we looked at each other it was possible to imagine it was a normal romantic night back home."

The couple live in separate communal quarters and rarely have time alone.

Rachel said: "I suppose the hardest thing is we are always surrounded by people but we try to go for a coffee or a run together so we have some time just for each other."

The couple, whose jobs involve co-ordinating flights in and out of Camp Bastion, took part in the base's half marathon on New Year's Day.

They recently returned to the UK on a break and took Gareth's eight-year-old daughter to Center Parcs.

Rachel said: "We both always knew that we would have to complete operational tours and to be honest we are lucky to be in the same place at the same time.

"The worst scenario would have been one of us returning from a six month tour just as the other was leaving.

"There are people out here who are away from their loved ones for months on end so it is nice to be here together and for each of us to understand what life is like in Afghanistan.

"We've been able to share the experience for all the good and bad parts. It's not our perfect honeymoon but it's worked surprisingly well."

Rachel and Gareth will return to the UK in May and have already planned a proper honeymoon in Rwanda and Tanzania.

Gareth said: "We plan to go on safari, do a bit of trekking and most of all lie on a beach together."

pages.subdeck: Millionaires ... Angel, Amber and Alby with Alfie's car
pages.headline: TV traveller family lotto joy
pages.teaser: MY Big Fat Gypsy Wedding stars celebrate £1m lotto win by splashing out on flash cars
pages.byline: By LIA NICHOLLS, Deputy Bizarre Editor
pages.articlebody:
CHILD stars of My Big Fat Gypsy Wedding are celebrating after their dad won £1million on the lottery.

Father-of-four Jason Stanley, 42, has already splashed out more than £250,000 on flash cars after scooping the fortune last month.

The Romany traveller also spent £200,000 on a brand new navy blue Bentley for himself and paid £50,000 for a Mercedes for his 17-year-old son Alfie.

And now his youngest daughter, Angel  who starred on the hit Channel 4 show in February  is waiting for him to treat her next.

The pretty 13-year-old said: "It's amazing. We're all over the moon.

"I've told him I'd like some money to put in the bank and some proper clothes  designer stuff.

"I want something nice to wear to the Appleby Horse Fair and a pair of Gina shoes."

She added: "My dad's Bentley is proper nice. Alfie is lucky getting that car, too."

Jason  who has separated from wife Simone  could not wait to cash in his winnings.

Angel  who featured on the show riding a horse and cart with her friends  revealed: "Dad didn't waste any time picking up the cheque."

She added: "He went straight out and bought the Bentley."

Angel breaks the gypsy norm by attending school.

She wants to study for her future rather than rely solely on a husband.

Horse dealer Jason took his four children  Angel, Alfie, Amber, 21 and Alby, nine  out for a slap-up Italian meal near to their home in Hayes, West London, to break the good news about his win.

Angel said: "Dad took us out for a really nice dinner to tell us all.

"Hopefully he'll buy another car for mum."

pages.headline: Terry could make £5m from 'Boycie' committee
pages.teaser: COUNCILLOR who helped Frank Lampard make a packet could also help his team-mate
pages.articlebody:
THE "Boycie" councillor who helped Frank Lampard make a packet sits on a committee that could let team-mate John Terry pocket £5million.

David Archer will help decide whether Chelsea and England ace Terry can build a massive lake next to his new mansion.

Archer  nicknamed Boycie because he looks like Del Boy's mate in TV's Only Fools and Horses  told The Sun he drinks socially with Lampard.

We recently revealed Archer filled in a planning application for Lampard, 33.

It was approved by Elmbridge Council and the value of Frank's home in Esher, Surrey, increased by £3million.

Next month the council's planning committee votes on Terry's application to create a private fishing lake on Green Belt land next to his mansion in nearby Oxshott.

If permission is granted the value of Terry's estate  which includes two large houses  could rise from about £11million to £16million.

Last night one angry neighbour of Terry, 31  speaking on the condition of anonymity  said: "There is a growing anger that footballers seem able to get through some major planning applications."

Fishing fan Terry has long desired his own lake.

There is no suggestion Terry, Lampard or Archer have done anything wrong.

Archer, 65, did not vote over Lampard's application because he declared an interest.

He has no interest in Terry's application.

Archer said: "They're my constituents. I wouldn't say friends."

Terry's spokesman declined to comment.

pages.headline: Tsunami ship is spotted off Canada
pages.teaser: FISHING boat swept away by giant wave is discovered with no crew 3,500 miles away
pages.articlebody:
A FISHING boat swept away by last year's Japanese tsunami has been spotted floating off Canada  3,500 miles away.

A plane crew discovered the 150ft craft about 160 miles west of the Haida Gwaii islands off British Columbia.

No one is believed to be aboard and experts says it is not a danger to the environment.

Japanese officials said the boat was lost from Hokkaido in the north of the country and its owner was listed as missing.

Millions of tons of debris were swept into the ocean following the earthquake and tsunami last year.

The boat is the first piece of large tsunami debris to reach North America.

pages.headline: Lair of beast who killed 7
pages.teaser: THIS is the bullet-riddled apartment where French terrorist Mohamed Merah made his last stand
pages.articlebody:
THIS is the bullet-riddled apartment where French terrorist Mohamed Merah made his bloody last stand.

The small Toulouse flat is littered with debris after 300 shots were fired during his final moments.

Video footage has been released showing the inside of the home where Merah, 23, planned chilling attacks in which he killed three soldiers, a Jewish school teacher and three pupils.

One wall is peppered with more than 30 bullet holes, while another has a huge hole blasted through. Grubby furniture including a sofa, a cupboard and an old mattress which Merah used as makeshift barricades can be seen.

The flat became a battleground when police stormed it on Thursday morning to get Merah. The al-Qaeda fanatic burst out of the bathroom and charged through his home, firing wildly before being shot on the balcony.

Merah had 20 bullet wounds but autopsy results show he was killed by sniper shots to his head and stomach.

Yesterday, neighbours were seen boarding windows hit in crossfire.

After hearing the students' accents, the Duke also asked the same Manchester lad and one from Sheffield: "Do you understand each other?"

Philip is famed for outrageous remarks. He once asked a visitor to Papua New Guinea: "You managed not to get eaten then?"

"He is kept away from the general prison population after threats to his safety."

Most days Murray  jailed for four years for involuntary manslaughter in November after Jackson, 50, died from a drug overdose  leaves his cell in tough Los Angeles County Jail only to go for a shower.

Every Monday night he is taken in shackles on to the roof for an hour to get some fresh air.

Bizarrely, his only chum inside is the ex-husband of Jacko's sister Janet.

pages.headline: Toxic breast implants killed my baby
pages.teaser: A GRIEVING mum has blamed toxic PIP breast implants for killing her unborn baby
pages.articlebody:
A GRIEVING mum has blamed toxic PIP breast implants for killing her unborn baby.

Suzanne Ellis believes son Ivan was stillborn after being poisoned by the ruptured implants.

She claimed they leaked industrial-strength silicone  which is used for stuffing mattresses  into her body.

Suzanne said doctors could find no other explanation for the death and is pressing for a probe into the tragedy.

She is also backing The Sun's Safer Surgery campaign for tighter regulations and a Government-backed national register of procedures.

Suzanne, 31, of Widnes, Cheshire, said: "When I decided to have implants, I thought I knew all the risks. I never thought losing my son would be one of them."

She had her breasts enlarged in Manchester in 2007. But after six months one started to swell and she had chest, ear and throat infections.

Suzanne, who has a 14-year-old daughter, then suffered chronic headaches before falling pregnant  when her symptoms got worse. She said: "I'd been pregnant before, but this was horrific."

She developed an intense itching across her body. Suzanne said: "I felt like there was something under my skin. It was awful." Doctors were baffled, but her unborn baby appeared to be OK and Suzanne called him Ivan. But at 27 weeks he was stillborn.

Suzanne said: "I needed answers but nobody could tell me why my perfect baby had died." She and her ex-partner Adam declined a post mortem at the time.

Tests showed a healthy placenta and the cause of death remained a mystery to consultants.

A year after her loss, Suzanne noticed a lump on her breast.

Doctors said her right implant had ruptured  and that it had been made by PIP.

The French company is at the centre of an international health scare over the faulty implants which were given to up to 40,000 British women.

Suzanne, who is waiting to have her implants removed, said: "No wonder I'd been so ill. No wonder my baby died. The manufacturers of PIP implants put my health at risk and risked the life of my son. How many other women have suffered?"

  • SUN doctor CAROL COOPER writes: Nobody knows if PIP implants killed Ivan. There have been no studies into whether they harm babies.

    Any implant is a "foreign body" and could provoke a reaction. Research is still being done. Pregnant women should get advice from their GP.

pages.headline: £80bn noose is choking UK firms
pages.teaser: SMALL businesses are being strangled by red tape which adds billions a year to running costs
pages.articlebody:
BRITAIN'S small businesses are being strangled by red tape which adds £80BILLION a year to running costs.

Fed-up bosses say if just one in ten potty rules and regulations was axed it would save enough cash to create up to 250,000 new jobs.

David Cameron has vowed to break down bureaucracy, much of it imposed by EU officials. But firms claim the PM has made matters worse by piling on extra red tape.

A Sun investigation has found thousands of the complex rules. Many bog down staff with forms or simply make it too costly to hire new staff. The barmy rules include:

SHOPS wanting to sell ant-killer or toilet descaler must apply for a £35 poisons licence.

A BOOZE licence is needed to sell chocolate liqueurs  and they cannot be displayed next to lingerie because it would link alcohol to sex.

STORE chiefs wanting to open a new warehouse face an 18-month battle  while rivals in Germany get up and running in just four months.

Chancellor George Osborne insists red tape reform has saved business £3.3billion and has vowed to shake-up planning laws to "get Britain building".

But Institute of Directors head Simon Walker said: "The more red tape there is, the harder it is to grow the economy.

"We've seen only minor changes when we need a revolutionary reduction."

A survey of 1,200 small and medium-sized firms by the British Chambers of Commerce found most feel choked by regulations.

The BCC estimates that the right to request flexible working hours will cost £4.8million a year.

The EU's working time directive, which forces firms to give workers extra time off if they fall ill on holiday, will hit small firms hard  with an annual £102.9million cost.

And shared parental leave, which gives both parents the right to take a chunk of time off work, will cost firms an estimated £20.5million a year. BCC director general John Longworth said: "Many businesses are already worried about the risk involved in taking on new workers."

Experts estimate that EU regulation alone has cost the UK economy £124BILLION since 1998.

Vincenzo Scarpetta, an analyst with think-tank Open Europe, said: "EU red tape still imposes huge and unnecessary costs on UK businesses, in turn hurting jobs and growth.

"The EU and the UK need to do far more to deliver on promises to cut regulation. We simply can't afford not to."

Britain is also the third slowest country in Europe for signing work deals  taking 161 days on average. That delays contracts to private firms.

In his 2010 election manifesto, Mr Cameron promised to sweep away red tape burdens created by Labour.

A month before the election, he declared: "It's time we brought business sense to Government and showed Britain is back open for business."

But a split in the coalition has seen the EU-friendly Lib Dems constantly resisting moves to opt out of Brussels diktats.

Measures to protect small firms were finally unveiled in October, leaving Mr Osborne and Business Secretary Vince Cable furious with other departments for dragging their feet.

d.wooding@the-sun.co.uk

CASE STUDIES: JENNA SLOAN & EMILY FAIRBURN

CHARITY BOSS

Matt Denning runs a kids' charity in Birminham

MATT, 26, raises money for kids with conditions such as cystic fibrosis or cancer.

He said: "I've encountered bureaucracy every step of the way.

"It took me 13 weeks to complete the paperwork to start up. Every time I filled in one form they asked me for another.

"I don't have an admin team, it's just me, and it seemed I was having to make calls and send emails all day, every day.

"I understand there must be stringent checks to stop people setting up fake charities, but things like asking for two separate police checks which show the same thing are taking it too far.

"I organised a cabaret evening and spent five hours handing out fliers to shops. The council took them down, saying they broke rules about how much window space can be used for advertising.

"It gets really frustrating. Cutting red tape would really help charities like mine."

MINIBUS SALES

David Fishwick owns a van and minibus firm in Lancs

DAVID, 40, has more than 35 employees on three sites.

He said: "Safety is my top priority and my minibuses are built to the highest standards. But needless red tape is costing my business thousands of pounds a year.

"EU regulations have changed so instead of hundreds of garages around the country who are able to issue a minibus with a safety certificate, there are now only five places in the entire country.

"That means waiting up to two months for an appointment, my guys having to drive for hours to get there, huge fuel costs and up to three hours of paperwork for each test certificate.

"I feel we live in Britain, so our courts and institutions should decide on what rules apply to us rather than the EU's.

"There is much more red tape today then when I started out. We need to return to common sense rule-making  that's what lacking at the moment."

PUPPETMASTER

Glyn Edwards does Punch & Judy shows in Sussex

GLYN, 69, has been a Punch and Judy man for 50 years.

He said: "With every booking I get a ton of forms from the local authority asking me to fill in risk assessments.

"My heart sinks. If you sit down and count up the time it takes to get through it all, the cost to the business really mounts up.

"Then I've been told to make announcements advising parents of the dangers of their kids sitting too long in the sun.

"And I've had to put blankets down to protect people from stones on the beach.

"A colleague said in his risk assessment that the only risk was the stand might blow over, so he puts out guy ropes.

"A council busybody decided they were a trip hazard and put warning signs on them. When the wind blew a sign flew off and whacked a child in his face, cutting his cheek.

"Officials have made themselves a laughing stock.

"So now I have two puppets in fluorescent jackets  Mr Tickbox and Mr Jobsworth  performing the ritual health and safety dance at the beginning of my show. It always gets a big laugh."

DRILLING CHIEF

Julie White runs D-Drill concrete drillers, Coventry

JULIE, 44, has around 100 employees.

She said: "A big business can afford people who do nothing else but deal with the red tape. This leaves everyone else free to get on with running the business.

"But in a smaller business it's the owners and managers who have to deal with it, when what they should be doing is winning new orders and delivering them to customers.

"Red tape gets in the way. For example, we did not bother applying for grants for our apprenticeship scheme because it would have cost us more than the grants were worth.

"And recently a training provider refused to give us names and details of people they would put forward for our apprentice scheme because this would breach the Data Protection Act.

"Jobs are scarce in the current climate, but the Government is hindering firms like mine from creating vacancies due to all the paperwork we have to negotiate.

"We need less and better regulation and streamlined procedures designed for business first and government second."

NEWSAGENT

Mavlin Patel has started his LA News shop in London

MAVLIN, 26, took over a newsagents six months ago.

He said: "It is a penny by penny business at the best of times  and in the current climate it's even worse.

"I'm finding it so hard to make any profit. Even worse than that, I have to spend some of that hard-earned cash on complying with red tape.

"And some of it is really silly stuff. They want me to change the fluorescent lights in the shop to tube lighting. What difference will that make?

"The council aren't helpful either. I need a secure storage box at the front of the shop where the delivery drivers can lock the papers.

"But the council reckon that obstructs the footpath so I can't have one. I can't afford to employ any staff so I have to get to my shop at 5am before the papers arrive and stay until 9pm. I'm exhausted.

"Some days when the papers arrive early the drivers have to just dump them on the street, and they get nicked.

"I'm just starting out so I simply can't afford to deal with all this red tape.

"I'm worried about the future of the business."

MyView

By SARAH BEENEY, TV property guru

RED tape is stifling economic growth in this country and it's a problem that urgently needs addressing.

It had a seriously detrimental effect when my husband and I were trying to bring an important historic building  Rise Hall in East Yorkshire  back to life. And that had additional knock-on effects in bringing employment and money to the local area.

The community and voluntary sectors have been particularly badly affected.

We must get back to common sense. I understand the need for rules and regulations, but when they become detrimental let's take them away.

pages.subdeck: High life ... Sun man Stewart Whittingham at the Droylsden dope farm
pages.headline: UK sells drugs to Amsterdam
pages.teaser: EXCLUSIVE: OFFICERS were greeted with bedrooms full of four-feet-high cannabis plants
pages.byline: By STEWART WHITTINGHAM and OLIVER HARVEY
pages.articlebody:
WITH the blinds tightly drawn day and night, there was something decidedly odd about the drab Edwardian home in Manchester's commuter belt.

Whoever lived at No 444 seemed to keep strange hours  and a radio blared out night and day.

But it was the pungent, aromatic smell coming from the property that made the neighbours in the quiet suburban terrace increasingly suspicious.

One described the strange stench coming from behind No 444's privet hedge as "overpowering".

And when police  accompanied by The Sun  smashed through the door this week, the misgivings of locals proved well-founded.

Officers were greeted with a sight more fitting to the Rif mountains of Morocco than the old mill town of Droylsden.

Sprouting in profusion in two upstairs bedrooms was a four-feet-high forest of plants with leaves resembling splayed fingers.

The house was a cannabis factory, one of THOUSANDS across the UK.

They are so common that it is feared British dope dealers are even smuggling the drug to EU countries including Holland and its notorious cannabis coffee shops.

For years Holland had a reputation for producing much of the strongest cannabis strains but British growers' increasing sophistication means they now farm potent varieties of their own for export.

Sentencing a Leeds cannabis farmer in December last year, Judge Kerry Macgill said: "What these courts find is that there is a cottage industry. We are also getting to the stage where we are exporting it to the places where we were importing it from."

One Brit said on an internet forum: "If you've been to a Dutch space café it looks like you could have been munching space cakes with THC (the chemical compound in cannabis) from an industrial unit just off the M1, or maybe a cash-strapped office worker from the burbs."

From inner-city council houses to trendy loft apartments and affluent town houses, UK cannabis cultivation is booming.

Some  known as "guerrilla growers"  even secretly plant cannabis on other people's land.

In 1997 only 11 per cent of cannabis sold on UK streets was grown here. A decade later the figure had passed 60 per cent and now it is believed to be closer to 80 per cent.

Much of the trade is run by Vietnamese and Chinese gangs. Some place immigrants, called "ghosts", in houses as plant-sitters. But British gangsters are increasingly muscling in on the huge profits involved.

A farm of 30 to 40 plants can make £5,000 every eight weeks  the time it takes for a new cannabis plant to flower.

Normally growers use multiple rooms so a second crop, propagated with cuttings from a "mother plant", can be grown while a first is harvested. Many concentrate on "connoisseur" brands such as White Widow, Blueberry or AK-47.

Nearly 7,000 cannabis factories, containing 750,000 plants, with an estimated yield valued at £85million, were discovered by police in 2009-10, double the figure two years earlier.

Former police officer Allen Morgan, 43, an expert witness in court cases involving cannabis farms, said last night: "It's an incredibly profitable business.

"It's potentially more profitable than cocaine dealing. There's no real outlay once you've bought the equipment. Growers usually bypass the electricity meters."

Allen said spin-off industries had sprouted up around the farms. He added: "Multi-skilled traders have grown up around the business. There are specialist gardeners, lighting and electricity experts. There is a market in growing equipment and seeds."

Since the economic downturn there has been an increase in the use of disused warehouses for production.

And recession-hit professionals have been tempted by the cash profits from drug dealers to rent rooms for growing the plants.

Landlords also unwittingly rent out properties to the gangs. In 2010 the four-bedroom home of one of Britain's most senior cops was turned into a factory for potent "skunk" cannabis. Rod Jarman, a deputy assistant commissioner at Scotland Yard, had rented out the £400,000 house in Abridge, Essex, through an online letting agent.

Criminals had run up a £20,000 electricity bill for the powerful lighting used to grow the plants.

Much of Britain's cannabis crop is exported. In the past three years 100kg of it has been seized by Customs at British ports or airports  a figure experts say is a fraction of the trade. There were 220 seizures of "outbound" cannabis at British ports between 2008 and 2011.

The Droylsden farm contained 116 "high-grade" female plants worth around £60,000. No one was home when cops burst in.

Luckily, the premises weren't booby-trapped. Police say gangs are taking extreme measures to ward off rivals. On one occasion, a garden gate at a house had been wired to the mains. Anyone touching the handle could have been severely injured or killed.

Once inside the Droylsden home officers heard a radio playing Barry Manilow's Copacabana. One of the Tactical Aid Unit officers revealed: "They often leave a radio on to make out to the neighbours that there's someone in."

Crooks had tried to mask the odour with air fresheners and by placing duct tape on windows.

They had bypassed the electricity meter so as not to draw attention to the lights for the plants. One resident, retired James Redmond, 66, said: "The guy next door told us he could smell the dope through the walls. It was overpowering."

In the past week alone, police based in Ashton-under-Lyne station have raided four cannabis farms seizing drugs with a street value of up to £500,000.

Police have uncovered 5,120 cannabis factories across the North West in three years. They contained more than 345,000 plants with an estimated value of £140million.

Cops use helicopters with thermal imaging cameras to detect the "glow" from the heat lamps.

Cannabis is Britain's most commonly used illegal drug. One in six people aged 16 to 24 had tried it in 2010/11 and an estimated two million people smoke it.

One inner-city dope dealer in Salford bragged that he used kids as young as 14 to tend to plants at dope farms. The 28-year-old said: "It was like a gang initiation for the kids. They were s*** scared. I'd use people who owed drug money."

Anyone running a farm can get up to 14 years in jail. The penalty for possession varies from an £80 fine to five years' imprisonment.

Detective Superintendent John Lyons, from Titan, the North West Regional Organised Crime Unit, said: "Cannabis is not the harmless drug it is often perceived as.

"An increasing number of people growing cannabis are funding dangerous, organised criminal gangs."

pages.headline: Banker's wife prays for miracle
pages.teaser: THE wife of shot banker German Gorbuntsov is praying for a miracle while he lies in a coma
pages.articlebody:
THE wife of gunned-down banker German Gorbuntsov was praying for a miracle last night as he clung to life in a coma.

Larisa Gorbuntsov, 46, wept as she held his hand, with gun cops on guard nearby.

A relative said: "German needs a miracle. Larisa has told us all to pray for him. She is in tears and cannot believe why this happened. She keeps asking, 'Why?'"

The Russian exile, 45, was blasted with a sub-machine gun in front of a blonde woman  not thought to have been Larisa  as he returned to his London flat.

He may have been shot up to six times  including in the face and back  as the assassination bid left his blood spattered all over foyer walls.

One neighbour said yesterday: "At about 7.30pm I heard a woman scream. I saw a blonde woman trying to flag down cars for help. She was hysterical.

"When I moved closer, it appeared he had been shot in the face and there were at least three holes to the back of his jacket."

The hitman fled on foot after Tuesday's attack near Canary Wharf, East London. Cops said his victim, in a medically induced coma, was "critical but stable".

The financier, who once owned Russian and Moldovan banks, is believed to have been targeted after witnessing a banker's Moscow shooting in 2009.

He is said to have confided to his lawyer: "If I go back to Russia, they will kill me."

pages.subdeck: Back on the box ... Simon Cowell
pages.headline: Simon Cowell: 'Rival show was a wake-up call'
pages.teaser: SIMON Cowell admits he is back on Britain's Got Talent because he feared The Voice would crush it without him
pages.articlebody:
SIMON Cowell has finally admitted the real reason he is back on Britain's Got Talent  because he feared The Voice would crush the show without him.

The 52-year-old summoned his entire BGT production team the moment he heard the BBC had bought the rival show.

He told The Sun: "Knowing that was on the horizon, I got all of our team over to America last year.

"I said, 'We're in a completely different place, this show has got to be the greatest series ever produced'."

He said the Beeb's move was a "wake-up call" for him. He likened it to when The X Factor winner Joe McElderry was robbed of the Christmas number one spot after an internet campaign to make Rage Against The Machine win.

Simon said: "If someone beats or competes, it means you've got to work better. And in a funny way the viewers benefit."

He added: "I thought I'd make a difference because I was in the mood to do it."

Amanda Holden is the only judge who has done all six series and Simon insists her position was never in doubt.

The line-up is now Simon, Amanda, Alesha Dixon and comedian David Walliams.

Simon said: "I couldn't do it without my Amanda. Alesha I've been after her for a long time and David I've wanted on the show for two years."

The BBC has lavished £22million on The Voice and Simon blasted them for refusing to admit they are in competition with his shows.

He said: "They wanted to have a pop at BGT because it's too popular and they don't like The X Factor being as popular as it is."

And he backed X Factor judge Tulisa Contostavlos to return  despite her sex tape shame.

He said: "I'm a hundred million per cent behind her."

As the latest series begins it has emerged BGT sensation Jonathan Antoine, 17, was so badly bullied about his weight that he suffered a nervous breakdown in October.

When the 20-stone teenager came on stage with friend Charlotte Jaconelli, 16, Simon could be heard whispering to guest judge Carmen Electra: "Just when you thought it can't get any worse."

But as the pair performed Celine Dion and Andrea Bocelli's The Prayer, Jonathan's incredible opera voice won a standing ovation.

On last night's show Simon asked Jonathan if he would consider ditching pal Charlotte  but Jonathan valiantly refused.

A spokesperson for mental health charity Mind welcomed the news BGT was supporting Jonathan  who is being monitored by a psychiatrist.

Meanwhile Sam Kelly, 19, of Norfolk, wowed the BGT panel playing guitar and singing Adele's version of Make You Feel My Love. Simon told him: "I've got to tell you Sam, when you've got absolute silence in a room like this, you've nailed it."

j.blackburn@the-sun.co.uk

myView



By JEN BLACKBURN, TV Reporter

"IT'S all about The Voice," boomed Sir Tom Jones as the BBC's glossy new £22million show set out to prove that it doesn't matter what you look like, as long as you can sing.

The BBC's X Factor alternative was brilliant, even if the judges spent more time boasting than judging.

But for my money it was a warm-up act for Britain's Got Talent, which has been revitalised by the addition of Alesha Dixon and a very cheeky David Walliams.

Beeb bosses seriously underestimated the cunning Simon Cowell, never short of a spanner to throw into the works.

BGT proved it still had plenty to offer as it closed with 20-stone teen Jonathan Antoine shuffling on  and showcasing his incredible talent.

But the biggest winners are the viewers, who now have months of brilliant Saturday night telly.

Alesha's all smiles



ALESHA Dixon says she is having more fun on Britain's Got Talent than she did on Strictly.

After three years as a judge on the BBC dance show, Alesha made the move to ITV after a big-money offer from Simon Cowell  and is sure it was a good call.

The 33-year-old said: "It's been brilliant. I've laughed a lot during this audition process  it's been crazy, in a good way.

"I feel more relaxed on this panel and I've been able to be more expressive and just have more fun with it."

Tulisa, 23, wants damages for breach of confidence and privacy after the video of her performing a sex act went up for sale on the internet.

The devastated beauty says Edwards is the man in the six-minute video. But he denies her claim that he leaked it.

Edwards has been hiding out in the West Country since the storm erupted and has been bombarded with abuse on Twitter by Tulisa fans.

The legal papers were served at a house where his mother lives in West Hampstead, North London. He was not there at the time.

A source close to Edwards, who calls himself MC Ultra, said last night: "She's suing for up to £100,000. This latest move by Tulisa has really unnerved and unsettled him.

"It's serious stuff and he's got to take it seriously. It's a lot of pressure for him."

A legal source said: "This is an unusual case, in that the injunction was granted AFTER the material became public, not before. It entitles Tulisa to seek damages."

pages.headline: Mam City
pages.teaser: WHILE £120k-a-week star lives in a mansion, birth mum moves to local council house
pages.articlebody:
MARIO Balotelli's mum has moved to one of Britain's toughest council estates as she rekindles her relationship with the son she gave away as a child.

While the £120,000-a-week footballer lives in a mansion and a plush hotel, Rose Barwuah rents a £550-a-month terraced house in part of Manchester made famous by TV's Shameless.

Manchester City striker Mario, 21, has visited her in Wythenshawe  driving his white Bentley GT, popping to shops and even standing his round in a pub.

A neighbour said: "Rose is a religious woman who goes to church every Sunday. All she has ever wanted was to rebuild their relationship and now it looks like her prayers have been answered."

Ghanaian immigrants Rose, 46, and hubby Thomas were advised to hand Mario to foster parents when he was two.

They were living in a cramped flat in Brescia, Italy, and he was recovering from operations on his intestines.

They said the richer Balotelli family who took him in then turned him against them.

The player dubbed Super Mario by fans went on to star for Inter Milan before being bought by City for £23million.

He reacted angrily when Rose and Thomas first said they want to be reunited with him, claiming they were just after his money.

But Rose, who barely speaks English, showed her determination for a reconciliation by moving with her 13-year-old daughter Angel.

Her other son, 18-year-old Enoch, is a promising footballer in England after trials with Stoke and Sunderland while daughter Abigail, 23, runs a fashion store near Milan.

Abigail told The Sun: "My mum will be closer to Mario and Enoch but I will stay here."

And Giuseppe Toninelli, owner of the metal works where Thomas has worked for 15 years, said: "He has left. He was going to Ghana before joining the family in Manchester.

"I think they are all trying to patch up their differences."

A neighbour in Wythenshawe said: "Rose is doing this herself to show it is not about money.

"This is the house she can afford. All she wants to do is to get to know her son.

"Rose has settled in here. She works at Wythenshawe Market, setting off before 6am to put out the stalls for traders.

"Mario has started coming round more often. He sometimes strolls to the shop for her.

"He has been friendly too and signed some kits. He has been to the local pub, The Tudor, and even put money behind the bar. It is lovely that he and Rose are close again."

Mario  who lives in posh Alderley Edge, Cheshire, and the city centre Hilton Hotel  played last night in City's 1-1 draw at Stoke.



His pad

AS well as his £3million mansion, Mario has been living in a £975-a-night suite at Manchester's five-star Hilton Hotel.

CLAIM TO FAME: Some of the most spectacular views over Manchester.

FACILITIES: Swimming pool, spa, ballroom.

FAMOUS FACES: TV stars plus players and WAGs from City and United.

CLAIM TO FAME: Created in the 1920s as a "garden city".

FACILITIES: Airport cargo centre, shopping mall, multi-storey car park.

pages.headline: Wills n Kate are Ange's pin-ups
pages.teaser: HOLLYWOOD actress is such a fan of the royal couple that she put their photo on her wall
pages.byline: By LIA NICHOLLS, Deputy Bizarre Editor

THE lovechild son of Sir Tom Jones has told of his agony at being rejected by the the Sex Bomb star.

Jonathan Jones Berkery, 23, has never met his dad  and said seeing him on BBC1's The Voice is stirring up his pain.

Jonathan  who sings under the name Jon Jones  is the son of model Katherine Berkery, who had a fling with married Tom in the US.

Sir Tom, 71, has paid £1,700-a-month maintenance for Jonathan but has always refused to meet him, claiming he was "trapped" by Katherine.

Jonathan is heartbroken that Tom  who has another son Mark Woodward, 55  refuses to accept him as one of the family.

He said: "When I tell people who my dad is they think I'm faking. All I want is to meet him once. Just to hear him say my name would be so cool."

Tom met Katherine, now 49, at a New York club in 1987. When Jonathan was born she took the singer to court to prove he was the dad.

Tom finally agreed to pay maintenance in 1998 when judge Judith Sheindlin  TV's Judge Judy  ordered him to take a paternity test. Even then he only publicly acknowledged Jonathan's existence in an interview in 2008.

Jonathan, who lives in America, was convinced his dad would come to see him as he grew up, and would sing his hits to his mum. He said: "I'd lie in bed imagining doing normal stuff with him.

"I thought he'd walk through the door, sit down and explain to me where he'd been. When I asked her, 'Where is he?' she'd tell me, 'He's an entertainer. He's busy. He can't be here right now'.

"I'd see him on TV and that made me feel better. I'd think, 'She's right. He has to do what he has to do, then he'll come home'."

Jonathan was ten when he realised it would never happen and he started to cry himself to sleep.

He said: "I can't respect him. He did what he did and he should have been man enough to take responsibility."

He said he still hopes Tom will one day hear him sing, adding: "It would be cool for him to know that I could."

A pal said yesterday: "Now that Tom's going to be big again with The Voice it's just going to rub salt in Jonathan's wounds.

"He'll now see him listening to the voices of strangers  after spending decades not bothering to hear his own son's fantastic voice."

pages.subdeck: On road to recovery ... Robin Gibb composed The Titanic Requiem while undergoing chemo
pages.headline: Robin Gibb: Writing Titanic music helped me to battle cancer
pages.teaser: HOW working on symphony marking 100 years since Titanic disaster helped Bee Gee
pages.articlebody:
IT is a maritime disaster that has always fascinated.

April 15 marks 100 years since the "unsinkable" liner RMS Titanic hit an iceberg on its maiden voyage and sank, claiming 1,517 lives.

In a series ahead of the anniversary, this week we explore stories of the Titanic.

Here pop legend Robin Gibb reveals the extraordinary personal circumstances which led to his interest in the tragedy and how it shaped his music.

HE has had a hand in writing some of pop music's most memorable hits, and has sold more than 200million records worldwide.

But it was writing a symphony about the sinking of the Titanic which helped pull Robin Gibb through a personal tragedy.

The Bee Gee has had a lifelong fascination with the ship, and to mark the 100th anniversary of the disaster he has composed his first classical work The Titanic Requiem, with son RJ, 29.

Robin says concentrating his energies on the piece helped him battle liver cancer.

He was diagnosed with the disease last year and is now recovering.

In an exclusive interview with The Sun, Robin, 62, said: "I'm truly grateful that working on The Titanic Requiem distracted me from my illness to such a degree that I truly believe it might have saved my life."

Robin's fascination with the Titanic story stems from boyhood, when he was caught up in a violent storm at sea.

He said: "One of my earliest memories goes back to when I was a little boy of seven and my grandmother told me how her mother cried floods of tears when she heard that the Titanic had sunk.

"Then, when I was eight and me and my family were sailing to Australia to start our musical career and begin a new life, we got caught in a monsoon.

"At times the waves flung the boat high, the next minute deep in a trough. The passengers were collapsing all over the deck and being sick but I wasn't.

"Then the captain made the announcement, 'Do not worry. There hasn't been a tragedy at sea since the Titanic went down in 1912'.

"It wasn't true, of course, or heartening for us passengers. But yet again, the spectre of the Titanic had been raised."

Robin, his brothers and their parents were almost killed at sea themselves when, in 1967 on the way back from Australia, their ship travelled through the Suez Canal.

He recalls: "A civil war was going on in Aden and our boat was fired upon. We were all ordered off the deck and into our cabins. It was quite exciting at the time but we could have all been killed."

That same year Robin narrowly missed losing his life again, when he and his then wife-to-be, Molly, were involved in the Hither Green rail disaster, in south London, in which 49 people died. He says: "I felt on top of the world that morning as the Bee Gees had just had a big hit with Massachusetts. Looking back, Massachusetts probably saved my life.

"Until that record hit the Top Ten I would never have been able to afford a First Class train ticket. But on that occasion, because Massachusetts was doing so well, I did.

"And like everyone else travelling First Class that day, both Molly and I had more chance of surviving the crash than those who weren't.

"But though we did survive, I saw harrowing things I've never forgotten.

"Headless bodies being dragged out of the train wreck, people screaming.

"Molly and I were rushed to hospital in Lewisham so we could be examined for injuries. I had broken glass from the train windows tangled in my hair.

"It took days to remove it but that was really the least of it. The shock and the horror was far, far worse. When we got to the hospital it looked like a war zone. All around us people were being carried in on stretchers and some of their injuries were horrific. Suddenly, it all became too much for me.

"The worst thing of all was that I was unable to help anyone, to mitigate their suffering, I couldn't cope with that.

"I knew I had to get away from all the carnage so I checked out of the hospital and instead went to stay with the Bee Gees' manager, Robert Stigwood.

"After that I suffered a delayed reaction. For days and days I couldn't stop crying. In the end the only thing which saved me was my music, composing with my brothers and singing again.

"But although I did recover, I'll never really forget the horror of the Hither Green train crash and the tragedy of all those poor souls who died or were injured in it."

Robin makes it clear that he does not think living through the rail disaster qualifies him for understanding the Titanic tragedy more than others. However, he believes it is easier for him to walk in the shoes of the doomed Titanic passengers.

As an avid collector of Titanic memorabilia, he has always been obsessed by the tragedy.

His collection includes a pen fashioned from pieces of the wreckage.

It was a present from second wife Dwina, who also gave one to RJ.

And that led him to change tack from composing pop music and, with RJ  also a talented musician  embark on composing his first classical work.

Robin adds: "It has taken us two years to complete The Titanic Requiem.

"Two years of dedication, and I'm definitely very proud of it."

RJ is also proud of the composition, and equally proud of his father's courage in working day and night on it while undergoing chemotherapy to combat his cancer.

RJ says: "He kept going on against all odds. He has been every inch a professional and he deserves a medal for it. For him to come straight out of chemotherapy and into the studio is incredible.

"We've always been close but working on a piece of music that is meant to last for hundreds of years brought us even closer.

"We composed the requiem in order to honour the memory of those who died and to celebrate the age in which they lived."

Robin adds: "I never pushed RJ to become a musician, though. I wanted him to excel at whatever he wanted to do but I never pressured him.

"As he grew older it turned out that he had a flare for melody, and like me and my brothers, who never had music lessons, he flourished. Our collaboration has been wonderful. We have already started working on our next joint classical composition, The First World War Requiem.

"But neither of us will be giving up pop music, either. RJ will be recording an album, Instant Love, and I will be working with Barry again, I'm looking forward to it.

"I just hope that The Titanic Requiem will be a fitting memorial for all those brave souls who died during the tragedy, so they will never be forgotten."

One of the most moving elements in the requiem is the song Don't Cry Alone, which Robin sings. It tells of a man who knows he is going to die begging his wife not to cry alone when he's gone.

It is a song that Dwina finds particularly emotional.

She says: "When Robin first played me the song he was in the middle of chemotherapy. I cried when I heard it. It brought up all my fears that I might lose him."

Robin jokes: "I was afraid that I might lose me, too. Luckily, I was wrong... "

  • The Titanic Requiem is released as an album tomorrow and will be performed in concert at Central Hall in London's Westminster on April 11. Tickets are available now. See robingibb.com.

pages.teaser: STUDENT Rearna has spent months planning her big day even though she's SINGLE
pages.articlebody:
STUDENT Rearna Ackord has been organising her wedding for six months.

The 22-year-old has selected the venue and picked out her £1,100 dream dress.

She has also chosen the song that will play as she walks down the aisle and finalised a menu her guests will be served.

But there is one thing missing from her big day  the groom.

She is one of a growing group of women called the Single Bridezillas, who have planned their weddings down to the last tea light, despite the fact they don't even have a boyfriend.

Rearna, who is reading English Literature at university, said: "Every girl grows up dreaming of their wedding day, fantasising about how they will look and whether their mum will cry.

"I'm just taking it one step further than most and making those dreams a reality."

Rearna was bitten by the bridal bug last year when she visited St Bartholomew's Church near where she studies in Brighton.

She said: "After a string of failed relationships, I used to be the type of girl who couldn't think of anything worse than getting married.

"But when, last year, I went inside that church I had a life-changing moment."

Taking in the beautiful architecture, long aisle and stunning stain glass windows Rearna was "blown away" by the place.

She said: "It was stunning. All of a sudden I could see myself in a gorgeous white dress, walking down the aisle with all my friends and family looking on proudly.

"In that moment I decided I had to get married and started planning straight away. I wanted to put my name on the wedding waiting list there and then."

Within minutes of returning home, Rearna decided both her dad Des, 54, and brother Landon, 19, would walk her down the aisle to the song A Case Of You by James Blake.

She said: "It's such a beautiful song, when I heard it on the radio I instantly said 'That's it'."

Ever since her visit to the church ten months ago, Rearna is "like a woman possessed."

Despite her friends mocking her sudden obsession with her fantasy wedding, Rearna hasn't stopped giving them details of her big day.

She admitted: "My friends laugh at me. They couldn't understand when I first told them I'd started to plan a wedding without a boyfriend.

"Suddenly, bridal shops and wedding magazines became interesting.

"Looking through them for ideas, my mind raced with thoughts of invites, flowers and, of course, the dress."

Rearna was in Uckfield, East Sussex, for a day when she saw an ivory dress on a mannequin in the window of Fross Wedding Collections.

She said: "I stopped in my tracks. I'd seen dresses I liked in the magazines but nothing compared to this.

"I knew straight away it was the dress I was going to get married in and booked an appointment for later that day to try it on.

"My friend Leah Butson  she's a student too  and I both had tears in our eyes as I twirled in front of the mirror with the circular train trailing behind me. It was the stuff of dreams."

Returning home that night, unable to stop thinking about her dream dress, Rearna began to panic that the dress would sell out before she had the funds to buy it.

She said: "I just know how upset I'll be if I finally saved up the money only to find out it's gone. The only way is to put down a deposit of £150, so I'm going to have to save so I can be safe in the knowledge it's mine.

"I go in to try it on at least once a month and because I've been doing it for the past seven months shop owner knows me by name.

"I've even considered taking out a loan to cover the £1,100 to put my mind at rest."

Rearna now visits the church every month to visualise her big day and measure up to work out how many flowers she will need.

She explained: "I sit and picture how it will look. I've planned to have the whole interior lit up with a thousand tea light candles and the pews to be draped with off-white silk. I love animals, so I've asked my best friend if her dogs can be involved. They're going to be dressed in little suits and dresses and will accompany the bridesmaids down the aisle.

"My friend Kirsty Naunton makes amazing cakes so I instantly got her on the phone to discuss what I wanted.

"The chosen cake is three tiers with white icing and diamante-style decorations."

To make sure her dream wedding will not become a distant fantasy, Rearna has made a pact with a close friend, 23-year-old Jonny Gregson, that if neither is married by the age of 30, they'll tie the knot.

She said: "Age 28 is my goal so I have a few years to find someone, finalise my plans and save the £30,000 I need."

Although she's missing a groom, Rearna couldn't wait to break the news to those who make up the rest of the bridal party.

Best friends Olivia Jones, 21, Leah, 22, Kirsty Naunton, 22, and Lil Griffin, 21, will all be bridesmaids.

She said: "Although they think I'm mad, they're all excited.

"I have already taken them to the shop to show them the pink dresses they'll be wearing."

With the ceremony planned in fine detail, Rearna will be taking her guests to the nearby beach for the reception in a giant marquee.

She said: "Living in Brighton, I've decided to have a party on the beach.

"Watching the sun set with my family and friends and new husband will be so amazing."

The single bride-to-be does not want to leave any part unplanned so Rearna has recently finalised her food menu.

She said: "My grandma Daisy Ackord is Jamaican and she makes the best food I've ever tasted, so she's in charge of catering for my big day. I'm going to have a West Indian menu consisting of jerk chicken, specialty rice and peas, ackee and saltfish and special Jamaican cakes for dessert."

Rearna and her gran have worked out the Caribbean feast will cost £50 a head. And for the music, she will hire a jazz-funk band.

She said: "I come from a very musical family and we're all big jazz fans so I've been keeping an eye out for one that can cater for weddings."

Every time someone mentions getting married, Rearna always tries to slip in a mention of St Bartholomew's.

The singleton even spoke to someone who had been married at the venue. When they revealed they had trouble with parking she immediately factored in plans to have minibuses bring guests to the venue.

Despite living on her student loan, Rearna is already trying to save the £30,000 she's worked out she needs for her big day.

She said: "The first thing I'm going to spend my first proper pay cheque on is my wedding dress.

"I'm completely obsessed with it and can't wait to have it hung in my wardrobe instead of in a shop window."

But Rearna is under no illusions  she knows the detail with which she has planned her big day could send a new boyfriend running a mile.

She said: "When I do meet someone I'll be keeping these plans firmly under wraps  until I have a ring on my finger..."

pages.teaser: A GRIEVING mum has blamed toxic PIP breast implants for killing her unborn baby
pages.articlebody:
A GRIEVING mum has blamed toxic PIP breast implants for killing her unborn baby.

Suzanne Ellis believes son Ivan was stillborn after being poisoned by the ruptured implants.

She claimed they leaked industrial-strength silicone  which is used for stuffing mattresses  into her body.

Suzanne said doctors could find no other explanation for the death and is pressing for a probe into the tragedy.

She is also backing The Sun's Safer Surgery campaign for tighter regulations and a Government-backed national register of procedures.

Suzanne, 31, of Widnes, Cheshire, said: "When I decided to have implants, I thought I knew all the risks. I never thought losing my son would be one of them."

She had her breasts enlarged in Manchester in 2007. But after six months one started to swell and she had chest, ear and throat infections.

Suzanne, who has a 14-year-old daughter, then suffered chronic headaches before falling pregnant  when her symptoms got worse. She said: "I'd been pregnant before, but this was horrific."

She developed an intense itching across her body. Suzanne said: "I felt like there was something under my skin. It was awful." Doctors were baffled, but her unborn baby appeared to be OK and Suzanne called him Ivan. But at 27 weeks he was stillborn.

Suzanne said: "I needed answers but nobody could tell me why my perfect baby had died." She and her ex-partner Adam declined a post mortem at the time.

Tests showed a healthy placenta and the cause of death remained a mystery to consultants.

A year after her loss, Suzanne noticed a lump on her breast.

Doctors said her right implant had ruptured  and that it had been made by PIP.

The French company is at the centre of an international health scare over the faulty implants which were given to up to 40,000 British women.

Suzanne, who is waiting to have her implants removed, said: "No wonder I'd been so ill. No wonder my baby died. The manufacturers of PIP implants put my health at risk and risked the life of my son. How many other women have suffered?"

  • SUN doctor CAROL COOPER writes: Nobody knows if PIP implants killed Ivan. There have been no studies into whether they harm babies.

    Any implant is a "foreign body" and could provoke a reaction. Research is still being done. Pregnant women should get advice from their GP.

pages.headline: Honeytrapper could be free in 3yrs
pages.teaser: DISTRAUGHT sister's fury at six-year sentence for 20-year-old honeytrapper Mundill Mahil
pages.articlebody:
STANDING in front of the shrine to her murdered brother, Amandip is distraught and angry  and feels betrayed.

TV boss Gagandip Singh was just 21 when he was lured to his death in a honeytrap  viciously beaten and burned alive in the boot of a Mercedes car.

Amandip, 19, a business studies student, said: "My mother and I are haunted by the way Gagandip was murdered. We saw his horrifically burned body and we cannot get that image out of our minds."

Medical student Mundill Mahil, 20, was jailed last month for six years for GBH with intent. Harvinder Shoker, also 20, got life for murder, while 20-year-old Darren Peters was jailed for 12 years for manslaughter.

Now, Amandip and her mum Tajinder have asked the Attorney General to review the sentence handed to Mahil and set up an e-petition, Justice For Gagandip.

Speaking out for the first time, Amandip added: "He would not have been murdered if Mundill Mahil hadn't lured him to her flat in Brighton in a carefully orchestrated honeytrap.

"Mahil will be released for good behaviour in three years. It's outrageous. Other cases involving money and fraud get much more punishment. Gagandip's life has been taken. I believe something more needs to be done."

Gagandip's body was found in the burning car in Blackheath, south-east London, in February last year.

He had been violently attacked in Brighton before being driven back to the capital and murdered.

A post-mortem examination revealed he was still alive when the fire in the car was started.

It was the second tragedy for the family in just 18 months. In September 2009 Gagandip's father Charanjit was murdered in India. Eight people are on trial there accused of being involved.

Gagandip took over his dad's packaging firm and also started the Sikh TV channel on Sky.

Amandip said: "We were only just starting to come to terms with the first murder when Gagan was killed. It has knocked the life out of me and Mum."

The court heard that Mahil, from Chatham, Kent, had been Gagandip's girlfriend. He was in love but they split up in August 2010 after she alleged he had sexually assaulted her.

Shoker, his friend of five years, also fell in love with Mahil and decided to take revenge on the businessman.

In February last year she lured Gagandip to her house in Brighton.

She knew that Shoker and Peters, both from London, would be lying in wait for him.

He was beaten unconscious and bundled into the boot of the car.

Amandip said: "I only met Mahil once, when Gagandip brought her to our home. She was very pretty and confident and seemed a nice person.

"My brother and I were very close and were both living at home and saw each other every day.

"He became very close to her and said she was a friend he trusted and who he could talk to about anything.

"Look at how she betrayed his trust. She tried to destroy my brother's character in court.

"But he was a kind, generous man who would have done anything to help anyone."

Detective Superintendent Damian Allain, who investigated the case, said after the conviction: "Throughout the investigation and trial Mahil portrayed herself as a victim.

"It is clear to me, now endorsed by the jury's verdict, that her actions were calculating and that she was at the heart of a criminal conspiracy with Shoker and Peters of tricking Gagandip to Brighton to seriously assault him, which resulted in his death."

The family say Gagandip had the world at his feet.

Amandip said: "He ran the family's successful employment agency and packaging business. He also set up and headed Sikh TV.

"In addition, he was the founder of the British Sikh Student Federation. He had made friends and contacts all around the world."

His mother Tajinder, 45, was equally proud of his achievements.

She said: "He had done so much. I didn't think a 21-year-old would be capable of so much.

"I'm amazed how much he achieved. Never a day goes by when we don't think about him.

"I am devastated by my son's killing and struggling to cope. In my life there's only a dead end.

"There's nothing left ahead. The whole story has finished here."

She now runs the family business, which employs 300 people. But with the emotional turmoil of losing her son she found it almost impossible to carry on with it.

She said: "When I first learned of Gagandip's death I was completely and utterly broken.

"I could barely function on a day-to-day basis and stumbled through each day not really knowing what was going on. I do not have the support of a husband because he also died not so long before Gagan.

"I cannot describe on an average day my life since Gagandip's death because they have all blended into one.

"In the early stages I couldn't hold a conversation without breaking down in tears and there were occasions when the police had to call an ambulance for me after I collapsed."

Cherished pictures from the family photo album show what a loving son and brother Gagandip was.

There was also a picture of him at his 21st birthday party with killer Shoker.

Amandip said: "Shoker turned up uninvited to the party.

"We knew things weren't right between Gagandip and Shoker by that stage. The photo of them together is so ironic as they look like the best of friends  and for over five years they were.

"I'm sickened by the thought that the man who holds his hand lovingly over my brother's heart in the photo is the same person who later beat him so terribly then burned him alive.

"He spent so much time around at our house that he practically lived here.

"What he did is such a terrible betrayal of trust."

Gagandip was cremated and his ashes scattered in a river at the Kiratpur Sahib temple in the Punjab, India.

Like her mother, Amandip broke down when she remembered the precious times they had together.

She said: "I found it hard to go into his bedroom without getting very upset."

Now, though, they remember him with the shrine in the garden and in his former bedroom in south east London.

Amandip said: "Mum and I actually slept in his room as a way of trying to feel closer to him.

"Now we have turned his bedroom into a shrine, with a large photo of him on the bed and all his clothes and possessions are still in the room."

Gagandip's mum and sister are still clearly in pain over his loss  but their grief would be easier to bear if they felt justice had been done.

Additional reporting: MARK CHRISTY
