CHICO Slimani has had a bust up with Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean ahead of tomorrow night's show.

The Dancing On Ice finalist was upset after the Olympians ordered him to recreate his topless Sexy And I Know It routine.

The former X Factor star has complained his back and wrist are too sore to do the spectacular seat lift where he has to raise partner Jodeyne Higgins above his head with just one hand.

And he fears that because he is in a topless costume, viewers will think he's trying to win votes by showing off his muscles.

He said: "I got a phone call and they said, 'Chris and Jayne want you to do Sexy And I Know It for the tour and could you do it for the final?' I thought, 'Here we go... people are going to say he can't skate, he's getting his body out for the vote,' and I've had a real problem with it."

However, after asking fans what they thought, he reluctantly agreed.

He said: "Then I thought to myself, 'Let the voting public decide.' So I went on Twitter and said, 'I can't really tell you what I am doing but what's your favourite routine if I had to do it?'

"Around 99.9 per cent of them said Sexy And I Know It. So I thought, 'OK, let's do it then.'"

But Chico has insisted on changes to the dance moves as weeks of training have left him with a bad back and a weak wrist.

He said: "I am having nightmares about it, to be honest. I have a back problem that I've got from the show and in all the weeks it had to come back  it's this week.

"I can't do one lift, I've had to change it because of my wrist  it's the seat lift where your hand is right up her bum!

"I managed to get her so far up but they wanted it travelling and turning and my wrist can't handle it so we had to change it."

But Chico admits he is pleased with his second routine  he is skating to Happy Days and will be dressed as The Fonz. He said: "I'm doing Happy Days which I'm really happy about because I get to be The Fonz  I've spent my whole life trying to be cool and now I've become cool by default.

"The Fonz is here and I have to walk up to everyone and I was like, 'Can't I just skate it?' They were like, 'No'  it's that that's driving me crazy."

Finalists also have to prepare their version of Torvill and Dean's Bolero.

He said: "With the Bolero, where we create our own routine, we have got the people at the top of their game at our beck and call to make our dream a reality.

Chico, who is up against Matthew Wolfenden and Jorgie Porter, added: "In this final, there is no room for error.

"The skating level has come up to such an extent that one slip, one error, one fall, will highlight it to such a degree."

DANCING On Ice star Jorgie Porter will perform the show's most dangerous ever stunt in a bid to win tomorrow night's Dancing On Ice final.

The Hollyoaks actress, 24, will be thrown up in the air by three male ice skaters, who will then spin around before catching her.

It is so dangerous that they have been practising with a carpet  which they keep dropping.

Until now Jorgie has wowed judges Robin Cousins, Katarina Witt and Louie Spence with her fearless approach to lifts and stunts with partner Matt Evers.

But the last lady celebrity skating in the competition admits she is suffering the first bout of fear about the daring trick for her final routine as she goes up against Chico Slimani and Matthew Wolfenden.

Injured skater Sylvain Longchambon, boyfriend of Jorgie's co-star Jennifer Metcalfe, is even making a comeback for the special stunt after recovering from a severe arm injury picked up in training.

Professional Mark Hanretty will also skate with them.

Jorgie, who has chosen Fame for her final dance, said: "There is definitely some scary stuff with my routine. We practised with a carpet and it absolutely collapsed and fell on the floor.

"I looked at it and went  'That's me!' I'm glad we practised with that first.

"There are three of them in a line, Sylvain, Matt and Mark, and I'm lying across them then they throw me in the air and spin around and catch me."

Jorgie was so terrified after they dropped the carpet that she made Jayne Torvill prove it was safe.

She said: "I was scared so I made Jayne do it first as well. She was really up for it. And she wanted to do the other parts too but the physio wouldn't let her.

"I've never said no, I've always been quite fearless throughout the show.

"But I thought they were lying when they were saying what they wanted to do with me. I thought, 'Is this a joke?'"

She added: "I still can't believe I'm the last girl standing.

"I think in days or weeks to come I'll be like, 'Oh my God, I did this'. At the minute I am just taking it in.

pages.headline: Motorway crash: Lorry driver dies
pages.teaser: POLICE refuse to speculate on cause of tragic M5 accident as bus driver is bailed
pages.articlebody:
THE driver of a lorry involved in an horrific motorway crash with a bus has died.

It comes after the bus driver, who was arrested on suspicion of causing death by dangerous driving over the accident, was bailed this morning.

The 49-year-old was held after a passenger was killed and 40 others injured when a lorry crashed into the back of his vehicle on the M5 yesterday.

One of the passengers on the bus, which was carrying a party of fruit pickers, remains in critical condition in hospital.

The bus was reported to have broken down in the nearside lane of the M5 before it was struck by the heavy goods vehicle at about 6.30am.

A 35-year-old man from the Smethwick area of the West Midlands, who was among at least 30 people travelling on the coach, was pronounced dead at the scene.

Another male passenger and the driver of the lorry, which was returning to Devon from Manchester, both suffered life-threatening injuries and were taken to the trauma unit at Birmingham's Queen Elizabeth Hospital.

Witnesses and a survivor of the crash said the accident happened after the coach came to a halt close to a footbridge in Bartley Green, Birmingham.

The lorry's cab was left embedded in the rear nearside of the coach following the collision, which also left debris strewn across the road.

A West Midlands Police spokesman said: "A 49-year-old bus driver from Birmingham has been arrested on suspicion of causing death by dangerous driving following a dawn crash on the M5 this morning.

"The arrested man has been released on police bail pending further inquiries."

The single-decker bus was not fitted with seatbelts and is thought to have been carrying fruit pickers en route from Birmingham to the Evesham area of Worcestershire.

Signs warning road users of fog in the area had been active since 4.46am but police declined to speculate whether low visibility was a contributory factor in the collision.

Chief Inspector Carl Flynn, of the Central Motorway Police Group, said: "This was a very serious collision which has tragically claimed one life.

"Emergency service personnel worked together in very difficult conditions to assist survivors and to ensure the safety of other road users.

"A thorough police investigation into the cause of the collision is now under way. This is likely to take some time and, at this stage, we will not speculate on the causes of the collision.

"I would like to extend my sympathies to the family and friends of the deceased, and our thoughts remain with the survivors and their loved ones."

Motorists faced lengthy queues in the immediate area as traffic police closed off the southbound carriageway to examine the accident scene, near to Frankley Services, and drafted in a police helicopter to take aerial photographs of the site.

Martin Stott, of the Highways Agency, told a press conference that signs warning of an incident and urging drivers to slow down were put in place after the initial call saying the coach had broken down.

Fog warnings were already in place, Mr Stott said, adding: "We'd set information across the network on our display signs to say that there was fog and to slow down."

pages.subdeck: Ready ... soldiers and police are on standby to avoid petrol crisis
pages.headline: Soldiers train to deliver petrol in case tanker drivers strike
pages.teaser: POLICE are also on standby to avoid the same chaos at the pumps that hit Britain in 2000
pages.articlebody:
HUNDREDS of soldiers are being trained to deliver petrol  in case tanker drivers go on strike next month.

Members of the Unite union are being balloted on strike action over their employment terms and conditions.

The Army and police are on standby to ensure fuel deliveries do not grind to a halt, resulting in the same chaos that hit Tony Blair's government in 2000.

Cabinet Office minister Francis Maude said the Government had "learnt the lessons" from the past and stood "ready to act" in the event of a walkout.

The results of the Unite ballot of 2,000 tanker drivers are expected today and a strike could begin from April 3.

Mr Maude appealed to the union and employers, including DHL and BP, to come to an agreement that averts industrial action.

But contingency plans are in place that could see soldiers being called in to drive tankers and police preventing blockades.

Mr Maude said: "We are calling on the trade union Unite and the employers involved to work together to reach an agreement that will avert industrial action.

"Widespread strike action affecting fuel supply at our supermarkets, garages and airports could cause disruption across the country.

"The general public should not and must not suffer from this dispute and strike action is manifestly not the answer.

"Although we are pushing for an agreement, we have learnt the lessons of the past and stand ready to act to minimise disruption to motorists, to industry and, in particular, to our emergency services, in the event of a strike."

Unite announced last month that it would ballot members working for seven major fuel distribution firms on whether to launch a campaign of industrial action.

The union warned that strikes could hit petrol supplies at supermarkets, garages and airports across the country.

The 2,000 drivers account for 90 per cent of those supplying petrol to UK forecourts.

Unite said there had been "unrelenting attacks" on drivers' terms and conditions, adding that it had been trying to establish a forum to agree industry-wide best practice on issues such as safety and training.

pages.subdeck: Front line ... Gareth and Rachel prove love can bloom on the battlefield
pages.headline: Newlywed soldier couple honeymoon in war-torn Helmand
pages.teaser: RACHEL and Gareth Mawsdley enjoy start of married life on the battlefield
pages.articlebody:
A NEWLYWED couple are enjoying a novel start to married life - with a honeymoon in war-torn Helmand.

Squadron Leader Rachel and Lieutenant Commander Gareth Mawsdley enjoyed a fairytale wedding at a Georgian manor house last year.

But they were only able to spend a few nights together before training began for their tours of Afghanistan.

The couple, who met through their roles in the military and live in Bath, both began a six-month spell at Camp Bastion, Britain's main military base in Afghanistan, in November.

While they admit a war zone would not be their first choice of honeymoon destination, they still find time for romance.

Rachel, 35, from Newbury near Reading, is in the RAF while Gareth, 32, from Liverpool, is in the Navy.

They recently marked their six month anniversary in a steak house on the desert base.

Gareth said: "There's no alcohol on base so we each had a can of pop instead of a bottle of wine.

"As we shared some nachos, we were surrounded by US marines and everybody was carrying weapons.

"But when we looked at each other it was possible to imagine it was a normal romantic night back home."

The couple live in separate communal quarters and rarely have time alone.

Rachel said: "I suppose the hardest thing is we are always surrounded by people but we try to go for a coffee or a run together so we have some time just for each other."

The couple, whose jobs involve co-ordinating flights in and out of Camp Bastion, took part in the base's half marathon on New Year's Day.

They recently returned to the UK on a break and took Gareth's eight-year-old daughter to Center Parcs.

Rachel said: "We both always knew that we would have to complete operational tours and to be honest we are lucky to be in the same place at the same time.

"The worst scenario would have been one of us returning from a six month tour just as the other was leaving.

"There are people out here who are away from their loved ones for months on end so it is nice to be here together and for each of us to understand what life is like in Afghanistan.

"We've been able to share the experience for all the good and bad parts. It's not our perfect honeymoon but it's worked surprisingly well."

Rachel and Gareth will return to the UK in May and have already planned a proper honeymoon in Rwanda and Tanzania.

Gareth said: "We plan to go on safari, do a bit of trekking and most of all lie on a beach together."

NOT a vote has been cast and already the Tories have managed to get taxes down.

Labour's surrender on 10 per cent extra cider duty is a triumph for David Cameron.

The Tories also blocked Labour's planned broadband tax.

Not a bad start as the Tories were clear winners on Day One of the election campaign.

In the Commons, Mr Cameron exposed Gordon Brown's weasel words over Labour's jobs tax.

Mr Brown says the business world has been deceived by the Tories into thinking that Labour's National Insurance tax rise will cost jobs.

Business leaders say Mr Brown is patronising, "economically illiterate" and insults their intelligence.

Almost seventy of Britain's biggest employers  including one of Mr Brown's own advisers  say the Tories are RIGHT.

The Sun agrees. Making firms pay more in tax for every person hired means bosses take on fewer workers.

Only in the warped world of Gordon Brown does raising National Insurance help unemployment.

The fed-up business community has washed its hands of union-run Labour.

Employers think that there will be more REAL jobs under the Tories.

Exactly what the country needs to hear.

Blaze heroes

FIREMEN didn't hesitate when they arrived at a blazing block of high-rise flats.

They plunged straight in  and two tragically lost their lives.

The Sun pays tribute to Hampshire fire heroes James Shears and Alan Bannon.

The brave men and women of our emergency services are very special.

When it comes to the crunch, they lay their lives on the line for us.

We are very lucky. We should be grateful and never forget their sacrifice.

Brave champ

TENNIS ace Martina Navratilova faces another tough challenge.

The legendary champ is diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 53.

Not even a superfit athlete like Martina is safe from a cancer that affects women indiscriminately.

Many Sun readers will have a relative or friend who has been struck down.

Cancer survival rates in Britain have improved over the years. But they lag behind much of Europe and America, where Martina is optimistic about her prospects.

Yes, times are tough. But our next Government must do much more to improve our record on survival rates for breast and other cancers.

Brave Martina, who never gave up on court, will not give up on this fight either.

pages.subdeck: Donations scandal ... Conservative Party co-treasurer Peter Cruddas
pages.headline: £250k gets you dinner with PM
pages.teaser: TORY fundraiser resigns after being filmed offering access to David Cameron for a donation
pages.byline: By DAVID WOODING, Associate Political Editor
pages.articlebody:
A TORY fundraiser quit early today after he was accused of brokering meetings with David Cameron in return for huge donations.

Co-treasurer Peter Cruddas was filmed offering a lobbyist and her two overseas clients direct access to the PM for £250,000.

The trader invited them to join the "premier league" of donors  adding there was no point "scratching around" with donations of £10,000.

David Cameron today called Cruddas's promises "completely unacceptable" and "shouldn't have happened".

Speaking at a Sports Relief run in Buckinghamshire, Mr Cameron added that there would be an inquiry to make sure such claims were never made again.

Labour MP David Miliband said this morning: "The idea that policy is for sale is grotesque."

Cruddas is said to have made the offer of access despite thinking the cash would come from Liechtenstein  which would be illegal.

Cruddas  worth an estimated £750million to £1billion  is heard boasting in a video: "Some of our bigger donors have been for dinner in Number 10 Downing Street in the Prime Minister's private apartment, with Samantha."

Cruddas  caught by a Sunday Times sting  also says: "Things will open up for you, but you need to go in with a bit of, you know  it's no good scratching around and it's ten grand or 75 grand."

He goes on: "A hundred grand is not premier league.

"It's not bad  it's probably bottom of the premier league. Two hundred grand or 250 is premier league.

"You will be able to ask him practically any question that you want."

He says later: "If you're unhappy about something, we'll listen to you and we'll put it into the policy committee at Number 10.

"It'll be awesome for your business."

After quitting early today Cruddas said: "I deeply regret any impression of impropriety arising from my bluster in that conversation.

"Clearly there is no question of donors being able to influence policy or gain undue access to politicians."

THIS is the bullet-riddled apartment where French terrorist Mohamed Merah made his bloody last stand.

The small Toulouse flat is littered with debris after 300 shots were fired during his final moments.

Video footage has been released showing the inside of the home where Merah, 23, planned chilling attacks in which he killed three soldiers, a Jewish school teacher and three pupils.

One wall is peppered with more than 30 bullet holes, while another has a huge hole blasted through. Grubby furniture including a sofa, a cupboard and an old mattress which Merah used as makeshift barricades can be seen.

The flat became a battleground when police stormed it on Thursday morning to get Merah. The al-Qaeda fanatic burst out of the bathroom and charged through his home, firing wildly before being shot on the balcony.

Merah had 20 bullet wounds but autopsy results show he was killed by sniper shots to his head and stomach.

Yesterday, neighbours were seen boarding windows hit in crossfire.

pages.teaser: TRAGIC David Rathband's widow has told for the first time of her devastation and agony at their split
pages.articlebody:
TRAGIC David Rathband's widow last night told for the first time of her agony at their split.

Mum of two Kath Rathband, 42, said the hero PC became withdrawn last August and their son Ashley heard him tell 7/7 survivor Lisa French he planned to leave.

Kath said: "David told her he was leaving me and the kids the next day. That was horrible, devastating. His behaviour had changed so much."

The next day in hospital he told nurses.

Kath added: "David turned to them, very matter-of-factly, and said, 'I'm leaving Kath'. They looked at him, astounded and said, 'How are you going to manage?'.

"His reply was, 'One of two things will happen. Either it will work out, or I'll kill myself'."

When Kath called a pal for advice, PC Rathband overheard and rowed with her. It was so serious Ashley called police who picked him up from the street.

Kath said: "I had never seen him angry like that."

PC Rathband, 44, hanged himself at his home in Blyth, Northumberland, after being shot and blinded by killer Raoul Moat, 37, in 2010.

Kath also revealed the PC's torment at night, when he would see Moat's face in the pillow.

He would scream, "Get him away from me."

In the interview it was also claimed he had numerous affairs.

She added: "I always loved him but I knew that emotionally he was weak. He loved me and the kids. I couldn't imagine living without him. And I know he would have made life incredibly difficult if I'd left."

It was approved by Elmbridge Council and the value of Frank's home in Esher, Surrey, increased by £3million.

Next month the council's planning committee votes on Terry's application to create a private fishing lake on Green Belt land next to his mansion in nearby Oxshott.

If permission is granted the value of Terry's estate  which includes two large houses  could rise from about £11million to £16million.

Last night one angry neighbour of Terry, 31  speaking on the condition of anonymity  said: "There is a growing anger that footballers seem able to get through some major planning applications."

Fishing fan Terry has long desired his own lake.

There is no suggestion Terry, Lampard or Archer have done anything wrong.

Archer, 65, did not vote over Lampard's application because he declared an interest.

SINGER Jarvis Cocker has lost a fight to stop a block of flats being built opposite his home.

The former Pulp frontman moaned that people in the new luxury residence would be able to see him in his pyjamas.

But developers have got the go-ahead for the scheme to turn a derelict cinema into 18 luxury flats in trendy Hoxton, East London.

Jarvis, 48, had complained to Hackney Council that the five storey building, which includes a new three-screen cinema, would be a "big ugly lump".

Speaking about the plans previously, he said: "I don't want people to see me parading about in my pyjamas."

Around 100 other residents also opposed the new building, saying it would block their light.

But developers First Quantum have been given the nod.

pages.subdeck: Accused ... Ian Mason
pages.headline: 'Abuser dad' trial halts due to cancer
pages.teaser: WOMAN allegedly abused by her dad is furious he escaped trial due to terminal cancer
pages.articlebody:
A WOMAN allegedly abused by her dad has told of her fury after he escaped trial because he has terminal cancer.

Ian Mason, 55, had been charged with a string of sex assaults on girls under 14.

Estranged daughter Amber Haigh, 28, was among his alleged victims.

Mason, who denied the charges, was due for trial  but last week prosecutors dropped the case after being told he has terminal lung cancer.

Amber, who claims he abused her for four years from the age of seven, said: "If we don't get to take this to court, in his eyes he'll die a free man."

Amber, from Plymouth, Devon, said it took years for her to tell her mum of the alleged abuse.

They confronted Mason  and another woman came forward with allegations.

But weeks later Mason found he had cancer.

The Crown Prosecution Service said he was unlikely to live long enough to serve a jail term, and dropped the case.

Angry Amber said: "I wanted him to face court."

Mason, seen smoking outside his house last week, refused to comment.

pages.headline: Grandad told: Play rugger to age of 65
pages.teaser: A GRANDAD has won the right to keep on playing rugby  after being told he was too old
pages.articlebody:
A GRANDAD has won the right to keep on playing rugby  after being told he was too old.

Stephen Clee, 57, was told to stop two years ago as rugby chiefs wouldn't insure over 55s.

But after a two-year battle he got them to change the rules  and he can carry on until 65.

Stephen said: "This is a moral victory for me. I'm really pleased they've changed things."

The U-turn by the Welsh Rugby Union means the new age limit applies to all players.

Stephen, of Tonyrefail, South Wales, added: "I thought the WRU shouldn't be able to dictate what age people can and can't play.

"I'm not the quickest any more  but it's a running joke in the club that I'm fitter and stronger than a lot of the lads in their 20s and 30s."

The Welsh Rugby Union said: "All clubs have been informed of the revised age limit."

England has no cut-off age, but players over 50 are asked to have regular medical checks.

The Rugby Football Union said there were "numerous people" playing well beyond 55.

pages.headline: Paedo is nicked by shopper
pages.teaser: JANE Gothard reported perv after spotting him prowling Sainsbury's with a camera
pages.articlebody:
A BRAVE shopper who held a man she suspected of taking indecent photos of children was praised by police yesterday.

Jane Gothard reported Mohamad Hatef to police after she saw him prowling the aisles of a Sainsbury's with a camera.

Two weeks later she spotted him again at the store in Alton, Hants, and caught him destroying phone memory cards.

She took his photo and detained him. Cops found indecent images of kids and he faced 32 charges.

Hatef, 52, was jailed for two years and placed on the Sex Offenders Register for life at Winchester Crown Court.

Mrs Gothard, 47, of Winchester, was congratulated at a police ceremony. Detective Constable Jacqueline Doran said later: "She opened a huge can of worms.

"The community should be grateful she acted in such a courageous way."

pages.headline: Jacko killer is sick in jail
pages.teaser: MICHAEL Jackson's jailed killer doctor Murray is wasting away after a stomach bug
pages.articlebody:
MICHAEL Jackson's killer doctor Conrad Murray is wasting away in jail after seeing little sunlight and being hit by a stomach bug.

He has grown pale and gaunt and has lost more than 20lbs.

A friend of 58-year-old Murray said: "Conrad doesn't look good. He has become really pale and thin. Some people even joke he's starting to look like Michael.

"He never sees the sun because he is never out in the daytime.

"He is kept away from the general prison population after threats to his safety."

Most days Murray  jailed for four years for involuntary manslaughter in November after Jackson, 50, died from a drug overdose  leaves his cell in tough Los Angeles County Jail only to go for a shower.

Every Monday night he is taken in shackles on to the roof for an hour to get some fresh air.

Bizarrely, his only chum inside is the ex-husband of Jacko's sister Janet.

Singer James DeBarge was jailed earlier this year for assault and drug offences.

The pal added: "They are getting on fine."

SIX men were remanded in custody yesterday accused of preying on vulnerable girls, grooming them for sex and rape.

They were among 13 men arrested in Oxford last week by police investigating claims 24 girls under 16 were targeted.

Hospital porter Akhtar Dogar, 31, his unemployed brother Anjum, 30, and security guard Kamar Jamil, 26, are charged with arranging prostitution of a child.

They are also accused of trafficking and conspiring to rape.

Akhtar and Jamil face charges of rape and a threat to kill.

pages.articlebody:
HOTLINES to report drought sneaks defying hosepipe bans are being set up by water chiefs.

Floods of calls are expected  after research found one in seven broke the last ban six years ago.

The shop-a-neighbour scheme was revealed as water companies vowed to get tough  amid claims the 2006 drought saw nobody actually prosecuted.

Thames Water boss Martin Baggs  whose customers will be among 22million in the south and east hit by the ban from April 5  vowed all calls would be taken seriously.

Nick Ellins, drought liaison advisor at Water UK  which represents suppliers  said: "When residents contact companies, it's because someone they know isn't doing their bit and they want something done about it."

An internet survey found 30 per cent of people would be prepared to report cheats  who face fines of up to £1,000.

But there was continuing fury among customers yesterday  as it emerged in one county alone enough water is lost in leaks to fill 300 Olympic swimming pools every day.

The total going down the drain in Kent is 286BILLION LITRES a year.

Jeff Scott, 43, of Tunbridge Wells, blasted the looming hose ban, saying: "They should get their fingers out and fix the pipes."

pages.teaser: FURIOUS Roberto Mancini refused to shake Tony Pulis' hand after a bitter elbow row last night
pages.articlebody:
FURIOUS Roberto Mancini refused to shake Tony Pulis' hand after a bitter elbow row last night.

Mancini watched his Manchester City side drop two priceless points in the title race after being held at Stoke.

Along with assistant David Platt he was seething at the rough-house tactics which left David Silva with a cut ear following a clash with Dean Whitehead.

Mancini blanked the post-match Press conference and Platt revealed: "He is not happy. He's worried he might say soemthing that gets him in hot water. It was really about the way the game unfolded.

"It's very intense and all he said was: 'You better go up because I don't trust myself.'

"There's not much point in me coming up and having a go at the referee.

"I know David Silva has a cut on his ear but I haven't seen it and I wouldn't accuse the player."

Platt confronted referee Howard Webb at the final whistle, while Mancini stepped on to the pitch to avoid a handshake with Potters boss Pulis.

Silva needed lengthy treatment following the Whitehead clash and returned to the pitch with his head heavily bandaged and there were a number of other challenges that riled Mancini.

Asked about Mancini's refusal to shake hands, Pulis said: "Mancini has got to do what has to do."

pages.teaser: OWEN COYLE has revealed that a private message from Fabrice Muamba inspired Bolton's basement-battle victory
pages.articlebody:
OWEN COYLE says a private message from Fabrice Muamba inspired Bolton's basement-battle victory.

Midfielder Muamba, in intensive care following his cardiac arrest at Spurs last week, wished his team-mates good luck for Saturday's emotional visit from Blackburn.

And David Wheater netted two goals for the first time in his career as the Trotters beat their in-form drop rivals 2-1 to move out of the bottom three.

Bolton boss Coyle said: "Fabrice managed to send us a message yesterday through one of the consultants to say he wished the lads well.

"It was great when we heard that.

"Our chairman has been in touch with (Fabrice's dad) Marcel this week and I am pretty sure the information about today's game has been passed on to Fabrice."

Coyle expects Marcel and Muamba's fiancee Shauna to tell the popular star, 23, that the Trotters are now on course to stay up.

The Bolton chief declined to say what words his team exchanged as they huddled together in victory.

He said: "It is a private thing. I wanted to thank everybody for their efforts.

"It has been an emotional week and the players were out on their feet at the end, both physically and mentally.

"But that is a small thing compared to the fight Fabrice has got."

Coyle added: "The team talk wasn't long today. Nothing is more important to us than Fabrice.

"If he is able to recover and have a great life with Shauna and his son Josh, that will be fantastic.

"But, God willing, he is able to play football again at this level, and if it is, our aim is for him to do that as a Premier League player."

Blackburn boss Steve Kean, who was equally dignified, said: "I told the lads to separate the occasion from the game.

"We wish Fabrice all the goodwill we can give but we had to play the match.

"The Bolton players had a spring in their step and once they got their noses in front it was difficult."

CHELSEA owner Roman Abramovich has ruled out an emotional return for Jose Mourinho.

The Special One, who secured six trophies in three seasons at Stamford Bridge, has refused to rule out quitting Real Madrid in the summer and completing what he claims is unfinished business at SW6.

SunSport exclusively revealed on Friday the Blues owner is ready to offer Barcelona boss Pep Guardiola a whopping four-year deal worth £40MILLION after tax in a bid to tempt him from the Nou Camp.

A highly placed Blues source said: "There is absolutely no way Roman will go back in for Jose  no way.

"Russians never go back, they replace things rather than fix them and they never admit they are wrong.

"For Roman to bring back Mourinho would be admitting to a very expensive mistake."

Abramovich was also said to be furious last month when Mourinho was house-hunting in London  and it was conveniently leaked at a time when the pressure on Chelsea boss Andre Villas-Boas had reached breaking point.

The source added: "It's convenient that Jose is always talking up a return when there are problems at other clubs. The same problems eventually led to his departure.

pages.subdeck: USED CAR ... Fergie with Tevez at United, before the Argy jumped ship to City
pages.headline: You're wrong about Tev, Fergie
pages.teaser: ROY KEANE says it is not desperate to bring Tev back  it is good management
pages.articlebody:
ALEX FERGUSON is wrong to call Carlos Tevez's return an act of desperation. It's called good management.

Manchester United have more to lose than City do with Tevez coming back because Ferguson will know full well that he is the sort of player who can turn tight games in his side's favour If he wasn't worried about City, would he even be talking about them?

Already, we have seen how Tevez set up the winner for Samir Nasri in City's 2-1 win over Chelsea on Wednesday at a time when they needed a spark.

You don't cut off your nose to spite your face and when you've a good player like Tevez you'd be crazy not to use him.

OK, Roberto Mancini had to be careful not to lose face in a situation where he had said Tevez would never play for the club again after he had refused to go on as a substitute.

But once Tevez apologised why wouldn't you bring him back? Ferguson is wrong, it's not desperation, just common sense.

Does he believe that Tevez should really never play for City again just because Mancini said he wouldn't after he refused to go on the pitch at Bayern Munich?

Ferguson has been around long enough to know things change and if you're going to apply those high standards then you had better make sure you are consistent.

Remember it was only last September that Paul Scholes revealed that he had refused to play for United in a League Cup tie against Arsenal in 2001.

There was no question at the time of Scholesy's United career being over even though he later admitted that what he had done was as bad  if not worse  than Tevez's actions.

You have to move on in football. Things happen in the heat of the moment but if people are calm and reasonable they can be worked out.

It might have suited United if Tevez didn't play for City for the rest of the season because he is a talent who increases their attacking options.

And Ferguson will be fully aware of Tevez's capabilities having worked with him at United.

He might have allowed him to leave Old Trafford but that doesn't mean he didn't rate him as a player.

He wouldn't have appreciated his carry-on when he tried to put pressure on him to give him a new contract but he will be aware of what an asset is he is on the pitch.

The fact that he made such a quick impact on his return to the fold will quell any discontent the City fans might feel about his behaviour and he has a role to play in the run-in.

He might not start but he doesn't need to because he reminds me of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer in his ability to get up to speed in a game almost as soon as he came on.

Remember that was his first game in five months and he still made his mark. Adrenaline could carry him through until the end of the season even if his fitness is not completely up to the mark.

The only reason Ferguson felt the need to have a pop at Tevez was because the mind games have started, the sure sign a title race has entered the title straight.

Once Patrick Vieira said bringing back Scholes was an act of desperation, he was always going to react.

That's what he does, defend his club and his players. I think he gets a buzz off it.

Some sports people like Muhammad Ali and Usain Bolt thrive off being in the headlines and creating them and I think Ferguson is the same.

In years gone by, we've seen him lock horns with Arsenal, Liverpool and Newcastle but this is a different ball game because the challenge is right on his doorstep.

He tried to put them down as 'noisy neighbours' before but City have kept coming and got stronger and stronger.

United feel threatened, there's no doubt about that.

In the past, Ferguson has got into rows with Arsene Wenger, Rafa Benitez and Kevin Keegan but the key is that his side have always been able to back him up.

United have walked the walk after he talked the talk so he hasn't been left with egg on his face.

Wouldn't it be a desperate irony if what he said about a former player came back to haunt him when the two sides meet on April 30?

Don't be so Kean

STEVE KEAN is getting a lot of plaudits right now  and, on the face of it, things have taken a turn for the better at Blackburn Rovers.

Three months ago, Blackburn were rooted to the foot of the table and the local paper and MP had both called on him to quit.

That's not to mention the fans whose opposition was so aggressive that he had hired a bodyguard.

Things have improved a bit in the meantime.

A run of five wins and three draws in 12 games has seen them climb off the foot of the table to 16th.

They are a full five points clear of the relegation zone and seem to have a bit of momentum that other sides have lacked. That is despite having to work under difficult circumstances.

His best player, Chris Samba, decided he did not want to play and was sold to Russian side Anzi after the English transfer window shut.

But can we actually say he is doing well just because they are no longer in the bottom three?

To me, it looks like Kean might be helped by the fact that other sides are not as competitive as in previous years.

Wolves and Wigan have taken just 22 points and Bolton only a point more. At the same stage last season, the bottom three  Wigan, Wolves and West Ham  had 27, 29 and 31 points respectively.

It is more a case of them not doing as badly as other teams.

And because he started off with people having such a low opinion of him, it seems like he is a no-lose situation.

If Blackburn do badly, people did not expect anything else and if they do OK, it's a bonus.

Still, not many would have expected him to turn it around as he has, so all credit to him for that.

pages.subdeck: OXING CLEVER ... Alex has proved a top buy for Arsenal
pages.headline: Ox can be our Roo
pages.teaser: TEEN sensation Alex has announced himself at the top level in style this year
pages.articlebody:
ROBIN VAN PERSIE has tipped Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain to be Arsenal's answer to Wayne Rooney.

The Ox has burst on to the scene with impressive displays this season  including a starring role in the Gunners' 3-0 Champions League win over AC Milan.

That performance saw the winger compared with Manchester United ace Rooney, who shot to world fame when he became the youngest player to score in European Championship history in 2004.

Arsenal boss Arsene Wenger has already said he believes Chamberlain, 18, is destined to gatecrash England's squad for this summer's tournament in Poland and Ukraine.

And Gunners skipper Van Persie has backed the teenager to have the same effect as Rooney.

The Dutchman said: "Alex can have a big impact. He has everything you need, I'm sure he has a bright future for Arsenal and England.

"He's shown that already in a couple of games.

"He has pace, he is clever, knows when to pass, when to keep the ball and has good technique.

"He's a bit like Rooney, who I rate highly. Rooney's a big player and a good all-rounder who can score goals, provide assists and make nice runs  he has a bit of everything.

"And although Alex plays on the left or right  whereas Rooney plays more through the middle  that could change in the future. They are both good all-round players."

Van Persie is the man currently firing the Gunners to glory.

This season has been his best in an Arsenal shirt with 33 goals to his name already but the 28-year-old Holland ace credits his team-mates and Wenger for making his scoring heroics possible.

He added: "I've been working with Arsene Wenger for eight years now and he's been a big influence on me, together with the team and the club.

"That's everyone from the kitman to the manager  they all help each other. Lots of my achievements are down to the rest of the players because, without them, I'm nothing.

"I'm not doing anything differently  I still love to play football and train but for the last 18 months I've been able to play week in, week out. You can see the results.

"Hopefully, I can stay in this form and keep it going."

Van Persie's scoring exploits have made him a frontrunner with bookies for this season's Player-of-the-Year accolade.

But he joked: "I've paid them off! We'll see. It would be special if I was picked as a candidate but that's for later."

pages.subdeck: UP IN ARMS ... Roberto Mancini cuts a frustrated figure at the Stadium of Light
pages.headline: Is Mancini cracking up?
pages.teaser: ROBERTO MANCINI could not trust himself to speak publicly after dropping two priceless points in the title race
pages.articlebody:
ROBERTO MANCINI could not trust himself to speak publicly after losing two priceless points in the title race.

Yes, he could point to Stoke's physical approach and whinge that his players had not had enough protection from ref Howard Webb.

Yes, he could claim that David Silva was the victim of a flying elbow and Mario Balotelli had been hauled down by an arm wrapped around his face.

But the truth is that the title heat is really getting to the volatile Italian.

The Manchester City manager erupted in fury on the day title rival  Manchester United boss Alex Ferguson  warned him he may not be able to handle Squeaky Bum Time.

It also came after a build-up which saw Fergie accuse Mancini of desperation for playing Carlos Tevez last week and which saw United star Rio Ferdinand claim City's fans had "come out of the woodwork" this season.

Yaya Toure's late strike cancelled out a Peter Crouch wonder goal to rescue City a draw at the Britannia Stadium and send them back to the top of the Premier League on goal difference.

But City have now won just two of their last nine away games and could fall three points behind Manchester United if the Reds beat Fulham tomorrow.

However, Mancini's defiant assistant David Platt says Fergie has not won the mind games war, insisting: "What are mind games?

"The team which wins the League will be said to have won the mind games.

"The be all and end all is about 11 players going out on the pitch and getting results. Words don't win leagues.

"I'm happy with the performance and Roberto is happy with it.

"People will say it's two points lost, but if we win the Premier League by a point it might be this point.

"The reason we're not pulling away is down to the fact United are having a good season."

Crouch scored a stunning volley before Yaya Toure levelled with a deflected drive. And Toure declared: "It's important not to panic. It is always difficult to play Stoke and the important thing is to work hard and believe in ourselves.

"We didn't deserve more than a draw today  Stoke played well.

"We gave ourselves problems, but it's important to keep going and wait until Monday, to see what United do."

His brother Kolo added: "It's always difficult here. We are disappointed to have dropped two points but it's still a good result. Every point is valuable."

Crouch's goal will live long in the memory as he teed up the ball with his right foot and delivered an incredible angled volley from wide outside the area.

He said: "I knew as soon as it left my foot I had a good chance. I was really pleased with the manner of the goal, it has to be up there with one of the best I've scored.

"I always enjoy volleying the ball in training but I don't get many like that. The lads will tell you I work on it every day, but it doesn't always pay off in games. It was great to see it fly in."

Crouch is now hoping to force his way back into the England squad for the Euro 2012 finals.

He added: "The aim has always been to do well for Stoke and hopefully get in the England set-up. I've been fortunate enough to play for my country a number of times and enjoyed every minute.

"I love playing here, they play to my strengths. The lads and the gaffer have been brilliant."

Pulis said: "It was a very good game. Crouch's goal was fantastic. He does that in training. It's not just a one-off and technically he's a gifted young man."

pages.headline: I should play instead of Drogba 'n Torres
pages.teaser: AND once he is top man at Chelsea, 'Studge' is certain he can be England's No1, too
pages.articlebody:
DANIEL STURRIDGE is an extremely self-assured young man. In fact, a more confident person would be difficult to find.

Too cocky, too selfish and with way too much swagger, some would say.

But, trust me, "Studge" will not budge.

He has a rock-solid focus on what he wants and where he wants to go.

Which is to the very top  with Chelsea and with England.

That is why he believes...

  • He can replace Wayne Rooney for England at Euro 2012.

  • He should play instead of Didier Drogba and Fernando Torres at Chelsea.

  • He will win silverware with the Blues this season.

  • It would be madness for him to change.

    His critics will say that is precisely his problem: too full of himself and too blinkered to others.

    But not our Daniel. He insists that is his strength.

    And sitting with him, listening to him, debating with him... you tend to agree.

    For here is a man who dares to be different, someone who will do it his way or die trying and you cannot help but admire that.

    Asked to describe himself, he replied: "I am young and free-thinking with new ideas and a new positivity.

    "I am an attacking player. I am young and fresh and I want to prove myself.

    "I am someone who is trying to champion a new way of playing  in my team, in my national team and in my career."

    See, told you he was not shy in coming forward.

    But there's more.

    Like his attitude to replacing the suspended Rooney in Poland and Ukraine.

    He added: "That's not going to faze me at all.

    "You only have one football career and in 10 years' time I don't want to look back and be depressed because I didn't achieve my targets. So I believe I can do it.

    "Wayne Rooney is obviously a world-class player, everyone knows that. But the one thing that's always driven me on is that desire to succeed, to be the best I can be. So I would love the opportunity."

    He might just get it.

    Sturridge was voted man of the match for England against the Netherlands at Wembley last month, despite coming on only as a first-half substitute and then hobbling off injured before the end.

    Ecstasy and agony in the same memorable moment.

    He recalled: "I was having a needle prodded into my toe at the time.

    "It was the Chelsea osteopath who told me I had got man of the match and I sort of snapped, 'Do you mind? I'm in a lot of pain right now'.

    "I just didn't believe him and it wasn't until I was leaving the stadium and was asked to do an interview that I realised it was true. Obviously, I was very pleased. They were my first serious minutes as an England player and I had done well at Wembley in front of so many great fans. That's a dream for every player.

    "And you can be sure I won't be opening that bottle of champagne, that's one for the mantelpiece  I just wish I had got it signed."

    Sturridge had a face like thunder when he was subbed for Fernando Torres in the thrilling Champions League win over Napoli the other night.

    And he would have been miserable consigned to the bench in this week's 2-1 loss at former club Manchester City.

    He has nothing personal against £50million Torres, nor Drogba for that matter.

    Studge just wants to be the main man down the middle for Chelsea.

    He insisted: "That's the position I will always pick myself, centre-forward."

    And added, less convincingly: "But whatever position the manager picks me in I'm happy and right now, for the team, I'm in the wide position.

    "I will always give 100 per cent and work as hard as I can to get the success we all want."

    Sturridge is used to battling for recognition and respect since his early days growing up in the Jewellery Quarter of Birmingham. He said: "I grew up in Hockley and was always surrounded by older kids and grown-ups.

    "My brother is older than me and I was always playing with him and his friends.

    "I was never in my own age group. I was always with the older lads but I didn't feel shy around them or inferior. I wasn't scared playing against them. I just wanted to prove myself.

    "Even then I wanted to be the best I could be. I was always trying to improve, to learn. I think that's what's given me so much confidence now in my own ability.

    "And that's why I will always try to express myself, even if I'm feeling less confident because I'm maybe having a bad patch.

    "Because I know everyone has bad times in every job, in everyone's life.

    "Everything doesn't run as smoothly as you would like all the time. So you have to persevere, believe and work as hard as you can to change what you are going through, to stay grounded and fully focused."

    That is especially true amid the inevitable uncertainty when you do not have a permanent manager at either club or country.

    He said: "Yes, it's a strange feeling. But it comes with the territory, it's part of football, part of life.

    "You just try to move forward as a group, whether it's with England or Chelsea."

    By moving on, he actually means aiming for the stars with the Blues and the Three Lions.

    Chelsea are chasing the Champions League, FA Cup and a top-four finish, ensuring a dramatic climax to the season. Then come the Euros.

    And Dan the Man said: "At Chelsea we want to finish the season off as well as we can, we have some big games coming up and if we can finish the season with some silverware it would be fantastic.

    "I am confident. I think it's going to be very exciting."

    But then life is never boring when you are Daniel Sturridge.

pages.headline: Fernando Alonso beats driving rain to win Malaysian Grand Prix
pages.teaser: FERRARI driver masters atrocious weather to claim victory at Sepang International Circuit
pages.byline: By BEN HUNT in Kuala Lumpur
pages.articlebody:
FERNADO ALONSO mastered atrocious weather conditions at the Sepang International Circuit to claim victory for Ferrari in the Malaysian Grand Prix.

The Spaniard turned in a faultless performance at the rain-delayed race but was pushed all the way by Sauber's Sergio Perez, who also put in an impressive drive to finish second.

Lewis Hamilton had to settle for third once again after starting on pole position, but it was a miserable day for his team-mate Jenson Button, who finished down in 14th place.

A shower five minutes before the start threw all the teams into a panic as the decision on whether to stick or twist with their tyre choice.

As the temperatures plummeted and the thunder and lightning gathered over the grid, McLaren's two drivers opted to stick with their intermediates.

It proved to be a lucky gamble, as Hamilton made a fantastic start after last weekend's disappointment in Australia where he surrendered his lead to Button.

There was no repeat here as both drivers narrowly avoided a collision with each other as they turned into the tight turn one at full pelt.

But while the two Brits went safely through, Michael Schumacher, who started the race in third, had a difficult time.

He quickly surrendered his position to Lotus' Romain Grosjean, who jumped up from sixth, but then on the exit Schumacher regained his position.

However, the two drivers did clash on turn four when the German was clipped from behind and went spinning before dropping to the rear of the pack.

Grosjean managed to regain his composure but suffered more hard luck on the first lap. As the rain continued to hammer down, he was due to come into the pits to swap on to the wet tyres.

However, while his pit crew were getting his new tyres ready, he spun off as his lost traction on lap five and ended in the kitty litter without having made it back to the pits.

It was incredibly unfortunate for Grosjean, who had given another solid performance in qualifying.

As the conditions took another turn for the worst, Button decided to come in for the wets having seen Ferrari's Felipe Massa benefit from the new tyres.

Hamilton followed suit, despite lasting another lap on the intermediates, before the rain became too heavy.

Button complained on this team radio that circuit was becoming too dangerous and said: "The last sector is like a lake".

Two bolts of lightning and a rumble of thunder seemed to rattle the race stewards, who quickly sent out the safety car on lap eight.

But even under the safety car, the conditions were becoming too dangerous and at the end of lap nine the race was red flagged.

After a delay of 51 minutes, the race resumed under the safety car for four more laps before it returned to normal conditions.

But it proved to be a nightmare restart for McLaren. First, Hamilton had a slow pitstop as the mechanic struggled with the rear jack.

He was then forced to wait behind Massa as Perez and Alonso took advantage.

There was even worse news for Button on lap 15 as he collided with the HRT of Narain Karthikeyan on turn nine and lost his front wing.

To add insult to injury he suffered punctures in his front tyres which forced him to make another pitstop.

It was another slow pitstop from McLaren, which dropped the Australian GP winner down to 21st place.

While Button was struggling, Ferrari's Alonso was able to set about building his lead over Sauber's Perez.

The Mexican has been linked with replacing Massa at Ferrari at the end of the season and gave added weight to his reputation with a number of quick laps.

Massa was having a difficult time, despite using the team's new chassis, as he made a poor mistake that allowed Paul Di Resta through.

Button was clearly furious at seeing his chances of winning wiped out and he took out his frustration, as he started ruthlessly cutting his way through the pack.

He pulled a brilliant move on the beleaguered Massa before being granted his wish to switch to the medium compound slick tyres.

But as Hamilton went in to make his stop for the slicks, a mechanic struggled to remove some sticky tape on his brake duct, which cost him even more time.

Perez continued to push Alonso to make for a thrilling final eight laps until he ran wide and gave his opponent more breathing space.

There was even more drama as reigning champion Sebastian Vettel suffered a puncture while he was in fourth place when he caught the front wing of Karthikeyan.

The subsequent pitstop and a KERS problem meant that he had to settle for 11th place.

pages.subdeck: SHOW OF SUPPORT ... fans spell out Fabrice Muamba's name in card tribute ahead of kick-off yesterday
pages.headline: Road to recovery
pages.teaser: YESTERDAY was another good day on the road to recovery for Fabrice Muamba
pages.articlebody:
THE applause was supposed to last for a minute.

In the end, it went on for a good five.

Young and old, big and small, fans of both Bolton Wanderers and Blackburn Rovers gave it their very best.

United by Fabrice Muamba, their old Lancashire rivalry suspended for a brief time.

Muamba may not have been there but he was foremost in everyone's thoughts.

Still seriously ill in hospital in East London, he will, nonetheless, have drawn immense strength from news of early Bolton goals at the Reebok.

Some will suggest that a relegation six-pointer pales into insignificance alongside what Muamba has been through since collapsing with a heart attack at White Hart Lane a week ago.

But, to the player, it will have been vitally important. And when the news of Bolton's victory finally filtered through to Bethnal Green, I'm sure it would have meant the world to him.

To know there was a little light at the end of the tunnel in his club's own fight for survival.

No doubt, he was kicking every ball. And, as best he could, joining in the applause.

And so everyone connected with Bolton finally got on with life yesterday. It was a day when even the sun came out for 23-year-old Muamba.

The Reebok is not known for the clemency of its weather.

Situated as it is underneath the aptly-named Winter Hill, it's one of the bleakest spots in the country, chill winds invading the very marrow of your bones.

Yesterday, though, it was bathed in sunshine. Suddenly, we were in Bolton-sur-mer. Smiling faces all round, girls in shorts and fans from both clubs gathered to see their teams do exactly as Muamba had wished  to get on with the game.

Outside the stadium, they read the messages of support.

On the ground outside the main reception area, there were shirts from probably every club in the land. And all with the same message.

Get well soon, Fabrice. Keep fighting. We're thinking of you.

Strangely, there was a sign on the wall saying In Remembrance.

Thankfully, this is not the case for young Fabrice, following his near-miraculous and ongoing recovery after his heart effectively stopped for 78 minutes last weekend.

There were further tributes to a player referred to as Lionheart. And an England shirt with the words Bulldog Spirit.

All very British and gung-ho.

Except Muamba is far from your average football player. He is a one-off, a man of his own making.

It takes a special person to arrive at a tender age from a country at war like the Congo and settle as well as he did.

To learn a foreign language in quick time and go on to pass three A levels.

And the whole time making an impression on the football pitch. Everyone has talked of what a delight Muamba is, considerate, patient and without a trace of conceit or envy.

How he has a kind word for everyone.

And also the time to take an Open University course in accountancy and attend church every Sunday.

As I said, far removed from the public perception of a Premier League footballer.

This, more than anything, is why we had a packed Reebok yesterday. Some 26,901, the biggest crowd of the season.

They had come to cheer their team and also say thank you. Thank you for Muamba being spared. And thank you for that rarity  a gentleman in sport. With the emphasis on 'gentle'.

As the players walked out, we were supposed to start our minute's applause. But it had already started.

And prompted, fair play to them, by the chants of "Fabrice Muamba" from the visiting fans.

As the applause continued, fans in the sun-drenched East Stand held up cards spelling "Muamba 6".

High to their right, the big screen recalled highlights of his career. And still the applause rang out. Then it was down to the other business of the day. And even there the sun radiated down on Bolton.

David Wheater powered home one header after 28 minutes, then another seven minutes later. And all was well with the world.

The name of the absent hero once again reverberated round the stadium.

Of course, these things never quite work to script. So we had Blackburn's Steven Nzonzi pulling one back with over half an hour left and high anxiety gripping the home fans.

Then, after a seeming eternity, a blast on referee Andre Marriner's whistle announced it was over and Bolton were out of the bottom three.

Yes, salvation may still be some way off.

But for Bolton and Fabrice Muamba, yesterday was another good day on the road to recovery.

pages.headline: Now you'll know what squeaky bum time is
pages.teaser: ALEX FERGUSON has warned Roberto Mancini he will find out exactly what 'squeaky bum time' is in the next few weeks
pages.articlebody:
ALEX FERGUSON has warned Roberto Mancini he will find out exactly what 'squeaky bum time' is in the next seven weeks.

Manchester City's Italian boss celebrated his team's crucial win over Chelsea on Wednesday by using one of Fergie's favourite phrases.

The two rivals will go toe-to-toe at the top of the table between now and May 13.

But Manchester United chief Ferguson says his team have proved time and time again they have the bottle to go the distance.

Asked whether Mancini really knew what 'Squeaky Bum Time' means, Fergie said: "He will in the next few weeks!"

City look to have the stronger squad following their spending spree but the Old Trafford boss says that does not always matter.

He said: "What's more important in the run-in is how the temperament is, how they hold their nerve.

"You look at it over the years. Last season we were 1-0 down at Blackburn and we needed a point to win the league.

"The energy of the team was unbelievable, it was incessant pressure until we got the penalty.

"We didn't bottle it and we never showed any signs of anxiety or nerves, we just kept on playing.

"Experience is important. It doesn't matter who you are, if you've been there before, it helps."

Ferguson is starting the mind games but he concedes the 'noisy neighbours' in Sky Blue have made huge progress.

He said: "City have done exceptionally well and they've been top of the league for a long time.

"In many ways they're in the driving seat because they've got us to come to the Etihad.

"What we've got to get used to  and it's the same for every United and City fan  is there's going to be big games involving the two teams for the next decade.

"It will be semi-finals and finals, whatever, because the two teams will be at the forefront."

pages.headline: We'll have to win all our games
pages.teaser: BLUES boss admits that Champions League bid is a long shot after draw v Spurs
pages.articlebody:
ROBERTO DI MATTEO admits Chelsea need to win all eight remaining Premier League games to have a hope of making next season's Champions League.

The Blues still trail Tottenham by five points after a Stamford Bridge stalemate with Harry Redknapp's side.

And Di Matteo said: "It's going to be difficult now but there are still eight games to play. To make the gap up we have to win all of them.

"Fourth spot is very important for this club."

Chelsea, who could also qualify by winning the Champions League, have away days at Arsenal and Liverpool as well as a home clash with Newcastle.

Spurs' run-in is not as daunting which is why Redknapp wants third.

He said: "It's not a done deal that Arsenal will finish third. We have to win six of the last eight.

"We would have a chance if we did that."

CHELSEA have stolen a march on home and European rivals by opening talks to sign Napoli's prolific marksman Edinson Cavani.

Representatives of the 25-year-old Uruguayan were in London on Friday to discuss a proposed £30million transfer to Stamford Bridge, even though Chelsea are currently managerless after the sacking of Andre Villas-Boas.

Cavani's stock continues to rise as he took his tally to 26 goals this term with a double strike to book Napoli's place in the final of the Coppa Italia in midweek.

Napoli maintain it will take a king's ransom to secure him  but Italian sources still believe they will cash in this summer.

Chelsea have been tracking the star and are in a position of strength compared to Premier League rivals.

Liverpool would like to pair him with his compatriot Luis Suarez but would need to finance the move by selling Andy Carroll.

Manchester City are also keen but to address new financial fair play rules they would need to sell before recruiting.

Chelsea's biggest competition will come from Real Madrid, Inter Milan and Bayern Munich.

pages.subdeck: PETER'S PERFECT ... Crouch's stunning volley gives Stoke City the lead
pages.headline: Stoke City 1 Man City 1
pages.teaser: PETER CROUCH smashed a wonder goal to shell-shock Man City but Yaya Toure hit back with a long range strike of his own as Roberto Mancini's side showed they are well up for the fight
pages.articlebody:
PETER CROUCH smashed a wonder goal to shell-shock Man City.

But Yaya Toure hit back with a long range strike of his own as Roberto Mancini's side edged back in front of their arch rivals in the red half of Manchester.

What little action happened in the first hour was all but forgotten when Crouch delivered a stupendous two-touch control and volley from 30 yards that flew over Joe Hart and became the main - if not ONLY - contender for goal of the season.

The game has started in timid fashion. The injured Sergio Aguero was replaced by Edin Dzeko and Carlos Tevez was again on the bench but the visitors did control the early possession.

But it was not until the ninth minute that Gael Clichy found space to deliver a ball into the Stoke box but Asmir Begovic claimed easily.

Stoke had their first opening after a free-kick was crossed to the back post for Crouch but Cameron Jerome was unable to turn his downward header goalwards.

At the other end, David Silva and Pablo Zabaleta both had efforts deflected wide and Yaya Toure shot over from distance.

Dean Whitehead was given a talking to by referee Howard Webb after catching Silva with his arm challenging for a high ball, with play held up while the Spaniard received treatment.

Stoke almost took the lead in the 41st minute when a Matthew Etherington corner was met by a deft glancing header from Ryan Shawcross but Pablo Zabaleta cleared off the line.

Mario Balotelli broke through as the first half went into injury time but shot tamely at Begovic.

Dzeko had a chance to break the deadlock in the opening minute of the second half as he controlled a lofted pass from Barry, but he could not get it down quick enough to round Begovic.

Cameron Jerome was replaced by Jermaine Pennant in the 51st minute and Hart was forced to block an effort from Walters at point-blank range.

Stoke claimed the lead with a sensational strike from Crouch just before the hour.

A long clearance from Begovic was headed on by the lanky front man, before he took the return from Pennant, flicked it up and twisted to volley over Hart and into the top corner.

Mancini reacted by sending on Adam Johnson for Silva and then Tevez for Barry in the hope of gaining more width.

But it was Yaya Toure from a central position - a non-threatening 35 yards out - who sledgehammered in the equaliser.

The Ivorian's firecracker caught the head of Shawcross and it was enough to wrong-foot Begovic and slam into the net.

Pulis introduced Wilson Palacios in place of Etherington to shore up his side and Shawcross came close with a header that looped agonisingly over.

Yaya Toure came close at the death but another powerful effort from the all-action midfielder flew just over the top.

pages.subdeck: GRET IN THERE! ... Bolton hero David Wheater celebrates with Rafn Steinsson
pages.headline: Bolton 2 Blackburn 1
pages.teaser: DAVID WHEATER'S first-half double lifted Bolton out of the drop zone and halted Rovers' revival
pages.articlebody:
DAVID WHEATER'S first-half headed double lifted Bolton out of the drop zone on an emotional day - and halted Blackburn's revival.

Steven Nzonzi nodded Rovers' consolation in a contest charged with feeling as it was Bolton;s first match since Fabrice Muamba's collapse last weekend.

StBolton manager Owen Coyle named an unchanged line-up from his side's last Premier League game as the Lancashire side aimed to put the emotion generated by Fabrice Muamba's cardiac arrest last week to one side against Blackburn at the Reebok Stadium.

With Muamba still in intensive care, none of Coyle's players took up the option of sitting the game out, instead committing themselves to try and gain three valuable points in pursuit of top-flight safety.

Blackburn have adopted a respectful tone in the build-up, but Steve Kean's men were chasing a third successive win and were also unchanged.

The Bolton supporters applauded from the moment the montage of Muamba began, right through until the handshake, a stand full of placards reading 'Muamba 6' held up opposite the directors' box.

It was soon evident the Bolton fans would be in full voice and Mark Davies fed David Ngog, whose cross was scrambled out of the Rovers penalty area.

Martin Petrov was inches away from finding Ngog with an intelligent through-ball that ended up running on to Paul Robinson.

Petrov let fly himself a couple of minutes later and Robinson had to watch the ball carefully in flight before beating it away.

There was little doubt Petrov was keen to make an impression and the Bulgarian shrugged Jason Lowe off the ball rather too easily, only to roll a disappointing shot wide of the far post.

Bolton keeper Adam Bogdan was thankful Davies was on hand to clear after he dropped Robinson's deep free-kick in a packed penalty area.

Ngog got his head to a Petrov cross at the other end, but his effort lacked power and Robinson gathered with ease.

Martin Olsson's diving header turned Petrov's deep cross away for a corner, which Bolton could make nothing of.

Blackburn should have had a penalty when in-form striker Junior Hoilett went charging into the box and was nudged over by Gretar Steinsson.

TV replays showed there had been contact with the man, and none with the ball, but referee Andre Marriner waved play on.

Bolton were indebted to Tim Ream, who slid in to ensure Yakubu did not get on the end of a Marcus Olsson cross that looked like presenting him with a tap-in.

And they immediately profited when Petrov crossed from the right and Steven Nzonzi only succeeded in flicking it on to David Wheater, who seemed as surprised as anyone when the ball ended up in the bottom corner.

Pratley was just off target as Bolton tried to press home their advantage, although Yakubu was inches away from equalising as he rose to meet Olsson's cross with a powerful header that just went wide.

Petrov's shot was touched behind by Robinson, which only offered Bolton the chance to cause more damage from the corner.

And this time there was no look of surprise as Wheater profited from Ryo Miyaichi's cross to power home his second.

Bogdan did not pay the penalty for yet more poor handling and not long afterwards Scott Dann's diving far-post header landed in the side-netting.

Martin Olsson needed treatment within seconds of the re-start after he was caught from behind by Miyaichi.

The full-back was able to continue, although as he was ushered back on to the field Miyaichi curled narrowly over for Bolton.

Wheater cleared after some slack play from Nigel Reo-Coker had almost put them in trouble and from the throw-in, Bogdan came to collect Nzonzi's back header.

Ngog was close to a third for Bolton at the other end as he rose to meet Petrov's inswinging cross.

Davies completely mis-kicked as he was presented with a shooting chance just outside the box.

And Bolton were made to pay as Bogdan failed to shift Yakubu from his line of vision until it was far too late as the hosts attempted to defend Morten Gamst Pedersen's corner and Nzonzi took advantage to nod home.

It was breathless stuff and Davies should have restored Bolton's two-goal cushion when Miyaichi picked him out from the right, completely unmarked, six yards out. Somehow though, he glanced the header wide.

Martin Olsson barged Steinsson off the ball by the corner flag but Hoilett let the pull-back run under his foot.

Bogdan needed treatment after taking a thud in the ribs from Yakubu.

In the meantime, David Dunn was introduced for Mauro Formica.

When play began again, Davies carved out an excellent opportunity for Petrov, but his shot nearly struck the corner flag it was so far wide.

Ivan Klasnic replaced Ngog 11 minutes from time as Petrov waited to take a corner which he eventually dropped on to Pratley's head. But he was off target too.

Yakubu bundled Hoilett's near-post cross just the wrong side of the post.

Blackburn were now looking to take advantage of Bolton's anxiety and Yakubu was not far away with a close-range header two minutes from time.

pages.teaser: CHELSEA missed the chance to move closer to the Champions League places after a stalemate at Stamford Bridge
pages.articlebody:
CHELSEA missed the chance to move to within two points of Spurs in the race for the Champions League places after a stalemate at Stamford Bridge.

In a boring first half only Rafael van der Vaart came close to scoring but his double chance was saved by Petr Cech and then blocked by Ashley Cole.

Juan Mata hit the post with a free-kick after the break as the Blues pressed for a much-needed win.

But it was Tottenham who came closest to nicking victory through William Gallas, Emmanuel Adebayor and then Gareth Bale who crashed a header against the bar.

Bale again tested Cech with a dipping last-minute free-kick but it was to remain goalless  a result which suits Spurs more than the Blues.

Fernando Torres was back on the bench as Didier Drogba returned to the Chelsea starting line-up.

But that change did little to ignite a surprisingly cagey opening.

The hosts looked the more threatening but any danger was well snuffed out by a Spurs defence without skipper Ledley King.

Scott Parker was his usual industrious self while Sandro was providing an effective shield in an unusually advanced role.

But in what has been such an exciting Premier League season the opening half of this London derby was a bore.

Despite the Blues in desperate need for three points to close the gap on fourth-placed Spurs, both teams seemed too scared to lose.

Chelsea did have a half-hearted penalty appeal when Frank Lampard broke in the box and went tumbling under a challenge by WGallas but Martin Atkinson rightly waved play on.

And Stamford Bridge had to wait until first-half injury time for the first real goalmouth action as Bale played in a neat ball to Luka Modric.

His deflected pull back found Van der Vaart ten yards out but the ball fell awkwardly on the Dutchman's right foot and he struck straight at Cech.

Cole then reacted quickly to block Van der Vaart's follow up and as the ball looped in the air, Adebayor could only head on to the roof of the net.

Things livened up a tad immediately after the break and Daniel Sturridge should have done better after Drogba headed him clear but he dragged his left-footed strike wide.

At the other end, Kyle Walker had Cech worried with a fierce right-footed drive after a lovely reverse pass by Bale but his effort crashed into the side of the net.

Ramires was up in arms after a coming together with Benoit Assou-Ekotto but Atkinson was again right to ignore the weakest of penalty claims.

Both sides were beginning to press forward with more purpose without either seriously threatening to get an opening goal.

That was until Juan Mata stepped up with a beautiful curling free-kick which had Brad Friedel beaten but struck his left post and bounced clear.

Then Spurs  having hardly threatened all game  had three glorious chances which all went begging.

First William Gallas headed over with a free header from a teasing Modric free-kick.

Then Adebayor latched on to a Modric dink but he lost his balance after rounding Cech and Gary Cahill was back to clear his strike at an empty net.

The visitors were then cursing their luck as Bale crashed a header from a corner smack on to the bar and Adebayor again headed the rebound over.

Lampard tested his luck at the other end with a strike from distance as Chelsea ran out of ideas.

But it was Bale again who came closest with a last-minute free-kick which had Cech scrambling to save and secure at least a point for his side.
